Pours a dark copper. Aroma of hops and a floral citrus.  Rich smooth taste of caramel and malted barley.  Hints of hops as well.  A+ beer all around.

2012 bottle. Been sitting on this for a little while and decided since I rated Dark Lord why not Behemoth. Pours a very classic deep copper colour with a very active white head that recedes to a nice coating and leaves behind a ton of lacing. Smells of very floral citrus hops, classic 3 Floyds scent. Tastes hop bitter, and it lingers for awhile. Theres malt in there as well, a little caramel. Ultra smooth. This will be stocked in the house for as long as I drink beer.

2012 vintage on tap at Sugar Maple in Milwaukee. deep red/orange pour with a small white head that doesnt last long. big citrus hop aroma from this one along with some caramel sweetness. taste follows the aroma with some sweet bitterness on the end.

Reddish orange pour with a nice head.  Kind of cloudy.  Aroma of citrus.  Smells more like an IPA than a Barley Wine.  Creamy mouth.  Taste is sweet with some sugary notes.  Finish is hoppy with nice citrus notes.  Ok lacing.  really dry finish.  Very tasty.

22oz bottle, gift from my mom that we shared a couple months after purchase. Clear amber color. Thin light khaki head. Leaving decent rows of lace. Barleywine? Drinking this relatively fresh, tastes more like a DIPA. But holy crap, it definitely does not taste like 12%. Very nice hoppy aroma. Nice grapefruit and pine. Nice, lighter crisp carbonation. Great bitter taste.. Mildly soapy? Enjoyable DIPA (I mean barley wine). I ought to let one age for a few years and see how it evolves.

Bottle. The pour was a cloudy medium honey copper with a large (2-3 finger) white rocky head that diminished slowly down to a large puddle and collar of foam which allowed for some excellent sheets of lacing. 

The aroma was of a caramel malt, pine hops and a moldy yeast with notes of caramel, citrus (grapefruit), dark fruit (cherries) and a slight alcohol tinge.

The taste was sweetly bitter with hints of caramel and dark fruit early on and then progressed into a more pronounced bitterness and mildly acidic with a strong hoppy citrus note and a decent alcohol finish. The flavor hung around for a very long time with a nice hoppy alcohol warming sensation left behind.

Mouthfeel was just below medium in body with an extremely dry texture and a medium carbonation.

Overall an exquisitely well balanced Barleywine with a nice fruity alcohol presence and a big dose of hops...

After the pour this looked like a beautiful amber jar of honey, where the eighth of an inch of head was the "thin layer of crystallized sugar."  The taste travelled through sweet fruit, warming alcohol, and was balanced by piney citrus hops.  As far as the style goes, this is incredibly approachable for barleywine beginners, and just as enjoyable for the most discerning drinkers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2012 release with red wax, 22 ounce poured into a tulip glass. Pours a deep caramel with a 1" head that quickly subsides. Nose is very hoppy, slight citrus aromas. Taste is hops with a slightly sweet caramel flavor. Very well balanced and easily drinkable. Fantastic brew!

Pours amber with cream colored head.  Smells grapefruit and hops.  Tastes a lot of malt, some caramel and some hop flavor with a little burn from the 12% ABV..  Not a fan of barleywines in general...but this one is decent.

Location: 22 oz bottle from jcos/dbarnold, 3/31/12, Red Wax 2011 Bottle


Aroma: The nose is a nice combination of caramel malts and  grapefruit, floral and resiny hops

Appearance: It pours an unclear dark orange-red color with a small off-white head and spotty lacing

Flavor: It has a big malty presence with a nice juicy/caramel sweetness, and a big heavy hop presence too

Palate: The body is full, with a thick, smooth, and creamy feel, a soft carbonation, and a lengthy duration.  Somehow it clocks in at over 10%, without having any heat.  It is both scarily and dangerously drinkable.

Overall Impression: 
This was my second fresh Behemoth of the month (as it is still March for another hour or so).  I decided to round out March 2012 (one of my highest rating months in some time) with this one.  Thanks for sharing when I was down there and then sending me home with another.  Im glad you guys have the regular Three Floyds hook-ups bringing their stuff out east.  Anyway, this is a great beer.  Highly recommended.  Ive heard it is better fresh, but that is pure hearsay, as I havent tried an aged one.
One of the best barleywines I have ever had. Hoppy, sweet and carmelly. Pours orange red. Tastes like it smells with dark fruity notes.

Sweet and smells like alcohol and caramel with tiny hints of cherry. It pours a sort of auburn red orange with half inch of white head, the carbonation is nice on the palate. Hits the roof of your mouth and the middle of your tongue simultaneously front to mid mouth feel. Flavor has a nice hop balance. Sweet, but not overly sweet by any means. Not as heavy as the barley wines I am use to, which comes across very nice. It hides the alcohol surprisingly well to me. Excellent beer. Thanks Hair6a11. What a wonderful first trade! Cheers.
Amber color with two fingers head. Hops are evident in the aroma.The hops in the taste are a little overwhelming and was probably intended for aging. Stills seems a bit unbalanced.
Purple wax. Opened in spring 2012.  Hazy amber orange with disappearing white head. Aroma is nice and resiny. Good strong flavor full of resin and fruits. Clean finish. Easy to drink.

Bottle. White wax. Pours a hazy golden with a beige head. Good lacing. Aroma is heavy and sweet, malty with notes of wood and citrus and pine hops. Flavour is rather sweet and fat, with hops, malt and caramel. Bitter hop finish with a bit of liquorice Slightly too much carbonation. Overall a well-balanced and quite nice beer. 17.02.12.

Bottle pours a ruby read nice large head. Tastes smells of dark fruit caramel pine hops. Not bad a bit sweet and to hoppy for me should been more roasty dark for my taste too much going on but still nice beer

Ruby red and formed an off white bubbly head that left trace lace as it subsided. An aroma of hops, heavy on caramel and pine. The flavor was of hops, malt, caramel and anise with a somewhat vinous taste. Medium light and fairly light for this style.

Tasted at Three Floyd's brewpub.  Pours copper.  Very smooth malty and fruity flavor.  Alcohol is not overwhelming.  Excellent beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at 3 Floyds.  Dark amber, thought I caught a bit of a reddish tint.  Fruity (almost reminded me off fruit cake) and caramel on the nose. Floral hops give this brew a real unique aroma.  A little alcohol on the finish but blended nicely with the hops.definitely warming quality....dont have much history tasting barley wines but I liked this one.

I normally dont rate beers, but I felt impelled after drinking one of these last night. First of all this is a great beer, if you want an imperial IPA. If your looking for a barley wine then look somewhere else. All barley wine characteristics this beer might contain are completely overpowered by a huge hop infusion of both taste and aroma. This beer should be labeled a imperial IPA. 

As an IPA I would give this beer a 7 out of 10. 

Probably wont be drinking this beer again since I paid $25 for a 22oz.

Notes from 10/4/11.  Deuce to tulip. Appearance (the most arbitrary category) is good; deep amber with little head. Smell is great for a barleywine. Probably the best bouquet of any unadulterated version (excludes barrel-aged BWs). Tastes great too. Everything youd expect from a 3 Floyds brew. Alcohol is present, but thats not a bad thing. Mouthfeel is good. While I dont subtract points from the heat of the abv in the taste category, it cost them slightly in mouthfeel. Overall, this is a great beer - that I wont be drinking too often because of the $17/bomber price.
Bottle shared at the RBWG in Austin.  Amber pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is dark fruit, caramel, and alcohol.  Taste is very malty, alcohol, more dark fruit, and a little earthy.

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a snifter

Ar:  Fruity aroma of grapefruit, light citrus, combined with a bit of toffee.

Ap:  Pours a golden amber with a one and a half  finger white head which slowly dissipates.  Beautiful lacing

T:  Pleasing citrus up front transitioning into a creamy caramel maltiness finishing in light biting citrus hops with slight undertones of pine. Just the right hints of sweetness.

P: Very creamy, silky, pleasantly sticky at the perfect times, and finishes extremely smooth.

O: This is a wonderful brew, above average in every respect. It is so drinkable, its dangerous at 10.5% abv. Youll definitely want more than one...

On tap @ Ale Emporium.
Deep amber brew with some creamy off-white head.  Nose of toffee, carmel, and some grassy and herbal hops.  Flavor is very malt forward with tons of caramel, some vanilla and a great hop bite.  I can only imagine how aweome this is with some age on it.

Probably my favorite barley wine.  Pours a caramel color with small head.  The aroma is lots of citrus, floral hops and some caramel.  Taste is more of the same with strong hop bitterness and a great rich malt balance.  One of the best beers out there.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2012 White Wax 2011 bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with minimal head.  Aroma is deeply fruity with notes of toast, citrus, and leather.  Taste is very smooth and medium sweet with a lightly hopped bitter finish.

22oz bottle at RBWG- Nose is dark fruits, hops, vanilla, caramel....Taste is caramel malts, chocolate, vanilla, citrus, dark fruits, Sweetness..Palate is thick with vanilla and alcohol lingering...A super solid barley wine..

From notes.  First reviewed 1/26/2011.  Served on tap in a tulip at Three Floyds.

This pours a turbid amber brown color with a modest eggshell colored head, which fades to a ring and leaves a smattering of lace.

Behemoth is a heavily hopped barleywine, for sure. Honey and caramel sweetness combine with floral and citrus hops. Soft booze in the background. Three Floyds has the scary ability to hide the booze in these 10% beers.

The taste starts sweet, but the alcohol is already present. Caramel provides most of the sweetness, with caramel and pale malts providing a nice backbone. The hops are mostly floral, with some citrus and light pine. A pretty big hop bill overall. Right now, I think I had to take off just a little since the flavor is good, but not that complex and a little raw.

Sticky sweet mouthfeel, with fuller than medium carbonation. The body is anything but behemoth, especially for the style and ABV. A very juicy feel.

Yea, I would definitely sip this for a while, it is quite enjoyable. Very sweet and hoppy, so I am intrigued to see how this would age.
UPDATED: JUN 18, 2015 Bitter finish, sweet barleywine aroma, not dense at all which is my main problem with barleywines. Rating 1300 fo. Sweetish flavors. This rock.

2011 bottle.

Deep orange and amber in color. Thick creamy white head at first that turns into almond color near the finish. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Moutthfeel is medium heavy, and full feeling with carbonation maybe slightly low, but very apropos for the beer. Taste is just outrageous! Lots of sweet malt, caramel, toffee, sugar, honey, and fruity hop flavors with a nice bitterness on the finish for balance. Awesome...so awesome.

2012 bottle in a duvel glass.

Nice deep amber/copper color. One inch head that lingers and never quite completely goes away. Nice lacing.

The aroma is fruity. I picked up pineapple, plum, citrus, and mild alcohol. This beer is well hopped.

The flavor is instantly sweet with a great hop burst. There are dark fruit flavors that mix with a slight toffee flavor and strong malt body. The alcohol is more apparent as the beer warms.

Overall this is an awesome barley wine and I will drink again and again. Probably my second favorite winter beer.

Bottle, 65cl, 2009. Pours a hazy copper with a tiny white head. Smells beautifully complex of prunes, wood, brown sugars, hops. Tastes of a medium bitterness, heavy sweetness, and liquid caramel, and lots of hops. Syrupy texture. Finishes cloyingly.

22oz bottle, white wax, 2011 vintage. Pours a deep, copper color with a big, off-white head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is malty, a little citrus hops, sweet bread. A little heavy on the palate with soft, smooth carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, caramel, toffee, a little pine hops, a little nutty, with a sweet, toffee finish. Excellent.

Bottle. 2012. Aroma is 3Fs signature hops... grapefruit, pineapple, pine... and caramel malt. Amber with a small off white head. Sweet caramel malt flavor balanced with sticky resinous citrus/ pine hops. Medium body.

22oz bottle at tasting, courtesy of Enjoyit - thanks a lot! Amber pour, nice off white head. Aroma is beautiful with buckets of American hops with aromas of pineapple and citrus. Then a gracious malt complexity of caramel, raisins and dates. Hints of passion fruit and fresh pie crust. Exactly what an American barleyed wine should smell like. The taste is very bitter and hoppy, but also has the same lovely malt profile. Raisins and figs - but not in a vulgar way that other barley wines have - its held back and subtle, yet present and perplexing. This is the best American barley wine Ive had, I must say.

Bomber. 2011 Release. Pours a copper orange with ample off white head. Big bold citrus and vanilla aroma. Taste is ripe citrus and caramel vanilla mix. Nicely blended with hop bitterness. Very nice for the barley wine style!!

Bomber, pours dark red, with some orange and brown highlights. Small off-white head. Nose is big on the citrus hops, nice brown sugar, caramel malts to back it up. Taste is hoppy bordering on slight tartness: a bit of grapefruit, ripe orange. Bit of pine, good toffee and caramel notes. Clean finish. Lived up to the hype.
Fresh bottle.  Lots of hops and lots of flavor, need to try to aged one.

2011 bottle shared by Josh, thanks! Pours a near clear caramel brown with a white head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a nice combination of grassy hops and sweet grains backed by a hint of caramel. Flavor begins with grassy hops that are backed by sweet grains and caramel. Smooth.

22oz bottle split at Madison tasting.  Really smooth and toasty, quite well balanced and drinkable.  Resinous hoppy  aftertaste.  None of the malty syrupiness i generally associate with  the style.  Right on, world class!

Ive tried several Barley Wines and Ive liked exactly 2 -- this being one of them. I reckon its largely due to 3 Floyds having some kind of magic Willy Wonka sort of power to make everything they do taste better than everyone elses -- this one is hoppy, creamy and is accompanied by a sweetness that is pleasant not cloying.

Great head, very hoppy for a barley wine.  Strong aroma.  Has almost an orangey flavor but hops tend to override everything else.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2011 Red Wax release.  Pours a clear, copper color with thin white head and little lacing.  Aromas of citrus, grapefruit, and pine.  Really surprised by that.   Taste is very IPA like.  Light sweetness, bitter hoppy flavor.  Alcohol hidden well.   Smooth, almost creamy mouthfeel.    Overall, this is a wonderful beer.  The great grapefruit bomb aroma is in your face at every sip.  The smooth sip erupts with a great balance of malts and hops.  Another great beer from FFF.

Dark brown color with ring of bubbles around the glass. No lacing, pretty oily mouth feel. Thick & malty with some light fruits. Nice complex flavor and little alcohol presence, surprisingly. Tasted good, but nothing spectacular. Honestly this is SOOOO OVERPRICED. $17.00 for a bomber? LOL.  Ive had so many amazing barley wines for 1/3 the price, I will never buy this again. Yes it was good, but was it 3X as good? NO. No, it wasnt.

Tap at 3F on 1/26/12.  Amber orange colored pour with a sticky bright white head.  Aroma of citrus hops and alcohol with a touch of sweetness.  I was expecting a big, hot, hoppy brew thatnwould want me to lay down the couple of bottles I purchased for at least 2 years.  Instead, I found Boehemoth to be quite drinkable now.  The hops are there for sure, but do not dominate.  Instead they add a nice citrussy brightness to the beer.  Thereslenty of malt as expected to hold it together and give a good mouthfeel.  The booze is very subdued.  This is quite good.  I picked up a few bombers and will rate 1 and 2 years from now...if they last that long.

Bottle, turquoise wax.
Amber, creamy beige head leaving lacing.
Aroma: butterscotch, tropical fruits, red berries, vanilla.
Taste: butterscotch, honey, medium bitter, some licorice, quite hoppy with citrus and pine, malty.
Full-bodied.
Great stuff!

Poured into a snifter. This is the super rare Ohio-only 2011 edition. 

4.0 A: Clear dark orange/amber color. Two fingers of creamy beige head. Retention is good for a brew of this magnitude and a good bit of semi-regular lacing is left.

4.0 S: This is a damn hoppy barleywine. You could call this a DIPA if you wanted to and get away with it. Hops give off a lot of tropical fruit with emphasis on orange and papaya, a touch of pine, and a pleasant herbalness. The malts offer plenty of peach and nectarine fruitiness, moderate caramel, and some neutral malty sweetness. To be honest, this shares a lot of traits with aged Nugget Nectar if it was able to hold onto its hoppiness.

4.0 T: Again, quite hoppy and probably closer to a malty DIPA than a hoppy barleywine. Tropical fruits again and this time pineapple joins the party. Mild to moderate bitterness. Herbalness and pine. Caramel, some toffee, and plenty of neutral, somewhat bready malty sweetness. Booze is apparent, but its not hot.

4.0 M: Heavier medium to lighter full body. Good moderate carbonation. A bit sticky, which I attribute mainly to the hops. Reasonably creamy and smooth.

4.0 D: Good, hoppy barleywine. At $16 per bottle, this is a very rare treat at best, but Im still going to buy a bottle for the cellar. Im quite curious to see what happens when the hops fade.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-11-2011 02:39:21

Bottle at Petrol Stations bottle share. Pours a cloudy amber with small off white head leaving spotty lacing along the glass. The aroma is a caramel malt and raisin. Medium mouthfeel with a Sweet hop and caramel with nice Smooth finish. A very good Barleywine from Three Floyds.

12 jan 2012, bottle. Hazy, orange/amber. Yellow raisins, alcohol, and bourbon aged stout that is heavy on the bourbon. Thin body and slightly syrupy candy. Wow! Candied bourbon aged barley wine. Smooth, vanilla, alcohol is hidden. Delicious! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Refrigerated green wax bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours opaque medium brown with upper portion being light brown to deep golden.  Medium body, little carbonation, and slightly sweet aroma.   Taste is caramel malt, alcohol, off sourness, and bitterness in the finish.  Apparently I do not like barley wines.

22 oz. bottle (2008 consumed in 2010).  Pours a hazy dark amber body with a small off-white head.  The aroma has sweet malts centering on caramel and toffee with notes of  pineapple rings and syrup, apricots, and citrus.  The flavor has a combination of caramel and pale malts with moderate sweetness.  Even after this much time, the fruits  and other hops are still present.  Citrusy hops provide a moderate bitterness to match the sweetness.  The alcohol is around, but this is a big beer.  The finish is bittersweet.  Medium-full body.  A tasty treat that I enjoy with a little bit of time on it.
very big taste: caramel/ malty/ toasty/ smoke/ grapey. The heat on this one was quite noticeable. the hop profile was complex and varied.

2011 bottle (yellow wax!) to New Belgium glass. Pours dark amber copper color with a little soapy off white head that fades to a wispy film. Aroma is awesome piny hops with a balanced mix of caramel sweet malt. Taste is just as above bitter pine hops and caramel with a warming finish. Palate is medium and slick that finishes warm and dry with a sticky feel throughout. Amazing barleywine! Thanks DalzAle for picking this up for me!

"07 vintage bottle.  Clear dark amber pour with a white head.  Fruity hop aromas.  Smooth with an abundance of rich caramel malt that are blended nicely with mellow tropical fruit hop flavors.  Surprised that the hops have held up so well for 4 years.  Another gem from 3F...

22oz bottle, yellow wax 2007.  Had this from notes bottle shared at REM release.  One of the best BWs Ive had.  Pours a wonderful caramel hue, slight head.  Aromas are filled with toffee, vanilla, caramel, and slight citrus from the hops still present in the nose.  Palate is tremendously balanced and smooth with a slight bittering finish.  Flavors and bold following the nose perfect, great weight too, nothing thin.  Would I say this could go longer?  Yes.  Ages so good.

2008 Purple wax bottle.  Part of Thanksgiving feast.  Pours a hazy reddish orange with an average off-white.  Aroma of hops, caramel and citrus.  Taste is oranges, cherries, caramel, piney hops and citric hops.  Some alcohol in the taste.  Well balanced.  Excellent !!!

Purple 2008 Bottle at Thanksgiving. Pours brown with lots of red and orange. Nose is hige malty with honey and sugar cane notes. First sip is resinous hops with crystal malt, honey & corn sugar. Finish is smooth with sweet doughy flavors.

Bottle...65cl....from trade with FullObs.. thx :)..It pours clear golden with a large white head.... the aroma is piny, citrus, hops, some fruits... the flavor is pine, caramel, hoppy, dark fruits.... It is very balanced.... very tasty and very nice mouthfeel... very nice  best barley wine.......

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2014 Vintage 2009. Pours almost clear amber with a white head . Aroma of big fat ripe fruits, like peach, plums, orange and some darker fruits. some syrup, caramel, toasted bread and a note of fainted hops behind. Taste is a bit more hoppy with some citrus, caramel, big ripe darker fruits, bready notes and some raisins. Big fat mofo American Barley Wine!

On my last pilgrimage to the Three Floyds Brewpub I was happy to hear that I didnt have to wait until January to try this.  They had just brewed a batch for their 15th anniversary.  The bottle had yellow wax and my favorite Three Floyds artwork on the label.  It pours a somwehat  hazy reddish amber with a small off-white head.  The first whiff wasnt too different from other Three Floyds brews Ive tried: loads of floral/citrus hops, but the only FFF Ive tried with caramel.  Taste is almost sweet, with a body almost as full as the picture of Miss Behemoth on the label.    Not very much carbonation and a finish more bitter/dry than the taste.  It hides the high ABV better than any other "high gravity" beer Ive tried.   I look forward to January when I can try another one of these.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 From the 11/2011 3R6P tasting.+++Sampled from a 22 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark caramel color with a medium sized off white head that left no lacing. The aroma was sweet and tangy with toasted caramel, pine and grapefruit. The flavor was sweet and tangy with intense grapefruit and pine and moderate toasted caramel and light cinnamon. The finish was long with caramel, pine and grapefruit lingering. Fairly full bodied. Excellent.

Bottle.
Medium gold.
Full bodied, medium sweetness, high bitterness.
Rich, malty taste, candied sugar, hops, dried fruits. Very complex. (2011-10-01)

Brown amber colour, small off-white head. Floral hoppy aroma, malts, caramel, quite spicy. Flavour is rather sweet, bitter, malty, caramel, pine and some roasted tones. Dry bitter finish. Nice.
(From 650mL bottle @ DRBM 2011)

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2012 Bottle @ home. 2010 vintage. Thanks to whomever sent this to me! Cloudy, reddish orange appearance with a tan head. Rich caramel malty, toffee, delicious fruity, piney, organic hoppy aroma. Red fruity, rich, toffee, caramel malty, fairly bitter piney, citrusy hoppy flavor. Delicious caramel, fruity, hoppy aftertaste. Holy shit the booze is hidden well. Excellent, smooth brew! Im very impressed!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2011 Poured on draft into a snifter. Appearance is translucent gold with a creamy white head of foam. Aroma is alcohol and rich malts. Taste is bitter hops that give way to a rich malty profile. Mouthfeel is soft with a warming presence that works its way from the tongue down to the bottom of the stomach.

Save this one for a cold, cold night.  It will warm you up.  Pours a reddish brown color with white head.  Aroma of carmel and grassy hops.  Taste is rasien, grapefruit, malts, and alcohol.  Outstanding barley wine.

66cl Bottle at DRBM. Clear orange colour, white head. Aroma is very strong hops, cheese, light caramel, malts. Flavour is sweet, malty, caramel, strong light cheesy pine and grassy hoppy bitterness. Medium bodied. Hops overpower everything, but still nice.
Golden copper, small head. Raisin hops, caramel, leather and ginger. Sharp taste, strong flavour. Dont like the body. (DRbM 2011)
Bottle @ drbm. Aroma is sweet malty caramel, spice and more. Flavour is massive hops, huge malt and caramel, loads of spices. Great barley wine. Lazy rate, awesome beer.
Bottle at UDRBM. Clear copper pour, thin off-white head. Aroma is thick malty barleywine, floral hops and alcohol. Flavor is sweet malty, madeira and pine hops. Very nice brew.

Sampled from a 2008 bottle. Poured an amber color, white head. Aroma was sweet malts, almost no hop character and a subtle gasoline waft at the end. Flavor was a bit boozy,, but more mellow than I expected based on the taste.

The nose is full of caramel malt and a mix of citrus and spicy hops. This brew is definitely big. Caramel malt, big kick from the hops, and pretty hot from the alcohol. As it warms, more malt complexity is coming through along with a few different hops varieties: grapefruit, pine, and spice.


The 10.5% ABV is evident, but it all adds to making this beer live up to its name.

And the lacing! This isnt rings of foam, its coating the entire glass.

Poured into snifter, pours a deep orangish copper tone, thin kkaki head. Aroma is quite hoppy, good malt backbone with caramel hints, hop hints of tropical fruit. Taste is hoppy but not a bitter hop flavor, the sweet caramel malt still shines through. Good creamy mouthfeel, good barleywine. Thank god we are finally getting some 3 floyds in ohio!

2009 Vintage large format in snifter.  A mix between the Dreadnaught and a typical barlywine.  There is some lemon apricot dreadnaught flavors and aromoas with sweet fig carmel barleywine flavors. Lingering bitterness, fizzy carbonation (small bubbles), sticky, thick.   For a barley wine I would say it is more bitter than sweet (more IPA like). Amber orange like color, tan lacing, slightlycloudy.  Stong alcohol flavors, much like a halls throat lozenge.

Sampled at Gothenburg Beer Festival 2011. September 3, 2011

Sweet aromas of malt, caramel, candy and tropical fruits like pineapple. Its very smooth and creamy with flavours of peaches, figs and hops. Its very heavy on the malt so Im glad theres some hops left to even it out. Of course its very balanced and refined but not really my style of beer.

On tap at the brewpub pours a dark amber with a small white head. Aroma is deep resinous pine with slight citrus and caramel malts. Taste is extremely fresh complex pine, citrus, bready yeast, sweet caramel, with a slight alcohol finish. This is by far my favorite barley wine, really enjoyed this fresh and cant wait to see how my 2010 bottle ages.

A typical FFF brew, great taste, bug price tag. This boozy beast pours a ruby carmely drown. There is a nice mix of malts hops and booze in the nose and in the taste. This is a BW that is as enjoyable fresh as it is with a few years on it. Very well balanced.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2012 Sample tried at Gothenburg Beer Festival on September 3. Unknown vintage but Id guess its from the latest batch. Pours an amber liquid with a white head. Smells like candy with some notes of apples and tropical fruit. Taste is of caramel and fruit in a perfect balance. The alcohol is there but it plays just the right role. A perfectly balanced beer and the greatest barley wine Ive tried.

2011 bottle poured into a snifter.  Dark orange with a nice off white head that gradually recedes.  Big fruity nose with caramel, pineapple, and alcohol.  Almost smells like a boozy pineapple upside cake.  The flavor starts off sweet and fruity.  Mid palate a strong hop bitterness comes and and perfectly balances out the sweet and fruity flavors.  A little bit of alcohol heat on the end.  Perfect carbonation and a medium to full body.  This is the best non barrel aged American barleywine that I have ever had.  I cant wait to visit this again after some time in the cellar.

2009 bottle carefully cellar aged pours murky amber with nice head cover and good retention.  Aroma is still the signature green apple of the fresh Behemoth, grapefruit, but has picked up notes of sherry, cardboard, tea, caramel, toffee and toasted grain.  Taste is caramel, hint of citrus peel, apple, toffee, toast, dry fruit.  Body is medium/heavy, creamy, softly carbonated, finishes bitter.  Overall, a great age on a great brew.

Glad i traded for this, one of the better non-barrel barleywines ive had really.
All kinda of complex caramel flavors from the malts that are cut through by the hops that give a citrus slash of brightness. This is one of the few barleywines i have had that is really really awesome and i feel the need to get more.

2008 Vintage
Very complex, its almost a mix between a Imperial IPA and a Barley Wine. It has some of the nice tropical fruit components of IIPA, but has the smoth and rich body of a Barley Wine. Flavor is lots of apricot, pineapple, figs, caramel. This goes down easy, the balance and how it gets the great fruit flavors together. I had no problem drinking a whole bottle alone.

Bomber with white wax; 2011 vintage.  Tasted in the 2011 BarleyBlind fest.  Pours orange in small glass. Aroma is very fruity and very hoppy, with caramel. Taste is fruity, citrus hoppy and sweet caramel. An easy drinker, some alcohol present.  Finished #2 in the blind tasting behind only Hog Heaven, and ahead of some good quality barleys.

Date: July 24, 2011 Mode: Bottle (2011 vintage) Source: BVery, Lakeville, MN Appearance: Translucent brownish orange with nice amount of head. Aroma: Sweet and hoppy. Flavor: Caramel, little bitter, alcohol, medium bodied. Other: Fantastic!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 Bottle. Wow. Amber orange pour with a big fluffy cream head. Monster aroma of caramel, malt, and sweet (booze). Semi dense palate. Taste is ridiculously complex and wonderful - similar to aroma with some vanilla as well. Killer beer.

Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated on 28.1.2010. Good barley wine with notes of sweetness, malts, caramel and hops. A bit too sweet for my taste. Couldve used some more aging, was a bit unbalanced.
Bottle @ FOneFan. Amber/copper with small off-white head. Flavour is malt, fruit, hops, caramel, vinous, little bitter, little citrus, nuts and grapefruit.
Thanks to Kiefdog for this yellow-waxer.  Very excellent barleywine, well balanced with both big malt and big hop, quite drinkable for the abv, held up well with a bit of age.

Blueish wax so should be a 2009 bottle. Pours golden amber with a white medium head that settles to a small but thick, dense head. Aroma is soft with notes of caramel, a blend of fruits and a hint of citrus. The flavour has a different approach to the fruitiness than most barley wines as it is not so muched heavy dried fruits but rather a smooth mix of fresh and dried. There are also flavours of spice and caramel. The keyword is smooth, only at first though cause after a while a soft bitterness kicks in.
Nose is coconut, raspberry, sour hops, little leaves, feel is watery, carb is low, taste is port, cane sugar, warm alcohol, then broad bitter hops.

22 oz. bottle from The Party Source in Bellevue, KY (2010 release with green wax).  Pours orangeish-brown with a foamy beige head.  Aroma of tangerine and grapefruit with enormous amounts of caramel, maple syrup, and brown sugar and hints of vanilla.  Incredible flavors of light whiskey and bourbon with fruity citrus hops and sweet caramel and brown sugar malts.  The mouthfeel is not too thin and the alcohol is well integrated.  Just about perfect in terms of a big American barleywine.

Bottle shared with Pat, Andrew, Dallas and Bobby. Pours a hazy reddish amber body with white lacing. Aroma is super fresh hops and some sweet caramel. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of fresh hops, pine, molasses, and sweet caramel.
Sessions with James, Dallas, Pat, and Bobby.  Very hoppy barley wine with caramelly notes.   Rich and supple.. Figs and molasses.
Bottle white wax. Guessing its 2011 series. Super hoppy aroma with slight head. Taste is very hoppy. Would love to put one away for a few years.

2009 on tap. Copper with a very little head.  Strong hop aroma of grapefruits, mango, and pine well backed up by big malt.  The flavor is huge with a balance of citrus,  caramel malts, molasses, and resiny hops. Silky mouthfeel. Remains balanced in the finish. Fantastic!

2008 bottle. Pours a hazy amber color with thin head. The aroma is a sweet, caramel and vanilla maltiness as will as a hint of bitter hops. The flavor is that of vanilla, caramel, malts and  toffee. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. Really enjoyed this beer.
2006 Bottle. Pours a murky brown with minimal head. Aroma of fruity caramel with some fading hops. Flavor of bright tea leaves, raisins, and a bit of resinous hops presence even with 5 years age.

On tap at Three Floyds Brewpub on 4-30-11 DLD. Pours brownish amber with very little head. Smells of pine, citrus and caramel malts. Wonderful malted carameland cereal grains, awesome hop profile, pine, grapefruit, and mango. Mouthfeel is thick and oily. Finish is long and bitter but with nice malt sweetness. Im glad I finally had this beer Ive waited for this a long time.
Bottle. Pours red/tan with a big beige head. Aroma is caramel, mollasses, nuts, and wood. Flavor is hops, caramel, toffee, and brown sugar. Medium/full mouthfeel nice heat.

Malzig-trockener und sehr gealtert wirkender Antrunk mit wenig Hopfen. Würzig-süß werdend, die Malzigkeit ist angenehm und in dieser Vollmundigkeit nicht erwartet. Dennoch wirkt das Aroma nicht übertrieben. Gut! /10/9/9/12/10

Pours a nice copper with a full white head.  Smells of fresh hops, if hops were considered juicy, this would be it!  Strong citrusy aroma with grapefruits, mangoes, pine, and earth.  The heavy malts really come through in the aroma as well.  An absolute delight!  The flavor is much the same offering the sweet citrus fruits, thick chewy caramel malts, and pine.  The finish ends bitter and sweet.  (not sure how, but it manages it!)

29-APR-2011, bottle @apartment in Barcelona, bought in "Ølbutikken". Saved for 1 year, blue wax.
Pours orange with lasting beige head. Very piney, bery grape fruity nose.
Taste is wonderfull. The same hoppyness. Almost liquor-like herbal taste that ends very bitter and very long.
Apart from the hoppy stuff, malty stuff kicks in as well.
Some bread and oranges. Sweetness is there but never cloying.
This is actually how I prefer my IIPA:-)
On the hoppy side but with a solid malty base.
Fantastic barley wine bordering on IIPA.
There is a herbal note that I cannot nail. I guess it is from the hops?
In no way alcoholic.
Just wonderfull.

2011 bottle. Pour ruby copper with beige head good lace. Aroma pine, citrus, grapefruit, resiny hops, mint, caramel sweetness, touch of booze. Taste cereal, booze warmth, caramel, butterscotch, grain, citrus, pine, resiny hops, grapefruit, orange peel, lemon zest extremely complex very balanced. MF sticky medium to full body with fine prickly carb and a great mouth coasting feel with great linger. Overall a exceptional brew that is unique, balanced, and super complex. A must have.
very sweet with a little bit of hops to it.  all and all a pretty good beer
Sweet caramel, barley and hoppy. Very malty and sweet, figs, bit of hops on the end. Pretty good.

2010 vintage shared by the other Matt, thanks Huhzubendah.

Beer is surprisingly yellow (although upon closer examination it is called BLONDE, Im not smart) with moderate to low carbonation and a thin white head of small and medium bubbles, not much lacing.

For a barelywine, it is quite hop forward, lots of resiny piny hop flavors in the nose...earthy at times too. I can pick up the malt but this is a hop bomb.

The leadoff here is alcohol and sweetness giving way in the midpalate to the pine hops. The hops are strong in flavor and force the palate to experience them, burying the alcohol significantly. I suppose this is one strategy to cover up alcohol, I wonder how this ages.

Serving type: bottle
En stor fruktig doft, fyllig och ganska len smak av frukt och kola. Het men ändå mycket lättdrucken.

Bottle, vintage 2010.

What a wonderful beer! Great aroma of malt, fruits, hops, resin, also some licorice. The taste was also excellent, maybe not a typical Barley Wine, not as thick as one might think. A winner for sure! Perfect beer to sip.

Bottle (2011), thx for sharing tarheels. Pour is gold/ruby with a big head and tons of lacing. Aroma is pine, mint, orange peel, and brandy. Taste is fresh, rich hops with a soft mouthfeel. Very easy drinking barleywine. Full of citrus, like biting into orange. Somewhere between a barleywine and a DIPA, but all you need to know its good stuff.

pours a light copper with a great two finger thicke light tan head. There is little carbonation, lacing is think but disappates quickly.

The beer smells hoppy with citrus, maybe banana, and some spice.

It tastes very smooth, light hoppy taste, smooth light bitter finsih.

2011. Pours a nice, see-through amber. Aroma is sticky and hoppy, lots of citrus character. Nice lemon rind, mango notes. Grapefruit somewhere in there. Taste is super sweet and malty, balanced bitterness. Finish is all wonderful hops. Lingering flavor, very sticky mouthfeel. Flavor is delightfully sweet with caramel notes and finishes with some very pleasant hop notes of orange peel and juicy tangerine. If this were as available as Bigfoot Id be homeless...

2011 Bottle thanks to Phaleslu. Pours hazed amber/brown, thick frothy beige head. Aroma has tons of fresh citrus hop (tangerine, pineapple) along with a nice malty sweetness, stone fruits. Dear sweet mother of Moses this beer is good. It tastes a lot like Donkey Punch, my highest rated beer, which was also a hop heavy BW. Except this beer is not as piney and resinous. Nice smooth texture, soft carbonation. Some medicinal alcohol notes come through. Very mild bitter finish. Fruity, Hoppy, Bold, Good Shit. Thanks again Peter.

Bomber thanks to p3t3r for sharing. Pours a a deep ruby gold color with a small off white creamy froth. Aroma of very sweet citric fruits. Overripe mango, tangerine and other tropical fruits abound, very hoppy along with a strong sweet caramely backbone. Flavor starts with a nice big juicy fruit sweet tropical character. Gains a slight piney note through the mouthfeel which stays very sweet and very overripe juicy fruit character. Finishes lightly bitter but very sweet and candylike. Medium to medium full body and a soft carbonation. Really nice IPA, not nearly as sticky as I thought it would be, but very fresh and tasty. Excellent stuff

650ml bottle with GREEN wax, 2010 vintage.

Pours into my snifter a deep red with hints of rose. Th head is large and froth and off-white. It recedes with very nice lacing.

This one still smells hoppier than hell, which is why I decided to try it now, Thre Floyds is all about the hops and I wanted to catch em fresh. Underneath the piney, slightly citrusy, maybe some tropics, hops there is a thick maltfest. It hasnt matured beyond a fresh, hoppy dipa scent yet.

The taste itself it hugely malty but with a nice hop bitterness and resinous pine flavors. But the malt shines in the taste. There are hints of caramel, brown sugar, oxidised apple, and scotch, never cloying but supremely decadent. The alcohol is present but not overbearing. 

The mouthfeel is syrupy thick though decently carbonated. It is ever so slightly cloying I guess. THe alcohol burns slightly especially int he lower throat. THe finish is somewhat dry and sticky as well. Drinkability is high, it goes down like a charm and warms the belly.

Another hit from FFF.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-22-2010 00:02:40

Bomber shared thx to Hjalmar/Magnus cons 2011-02-26 Göteborg
AR: ear wax, vinos, plum
AP: orange/amber, wee white head
F: alcohol, tocadero, victoria plums

Courtesy of gnoff. Pours hazy dark amber with a small bubbly beige head. Aroma is fullbodied sweet, honey, madeira, raisins, malty, hoppy and fruity. Fulllbodied fruity sweet mouthfeel. Tart, fruity, sweet well balanced flavor. Fruity sweet palate. Finishes sweet tart hoppy.

I tried the purple wax bottle. Just a all around perfect beer. Looks great with an aroma that is present. The taste is incredible. Tons of flavor. Kept getting alot of sweet grapish citrus notes. Really enjoyed this beer definitely an A+ brew. This bottle must have been aged a couple years and was great. I want to try the fresh white wax bottle to see how it compares.

This has to be one of my favorite brews. Sweet, hoppy, malty. A perfect balance. The palate and finish is perfect. The nose is pine. Amazing. The taste is outragious. Crisp and perefect carbonation. My favorite barley wine.
On tap at brewpub. Amber with thin white head. Aroma is caramel. Flavor is caramel, pine and grapefruit. Very nice barley-wine, but I remember the 2010 vintage being better than the 2011.

Had at Brickskeller during Savour 2010 week tasting event. Second to last beer in order of Gumballhead, Robert The Bruce, Topless Wytch, Alpha King, Blackheart, Dreadnaught, then followed by Dark Lord. Amazing night.  Covers alcohol well - maybe cause at that point my taste buds were worked over.

I loved it! I had the 2009. Of course it was hops for all and I was delighted that in its sweetness. I think I picked up on banana, peach, and caramels. I had it at a Super Bowl party and it F#%*ed me up. I fell asleep on the couch in the fourth quarter. Taste great and will put you down for the count if your not careful.

Aroma: Extremely malty and rich, nuts, jam, alcohol, honey, toffee, earthy hops in the back, caramel, has a fruity quality as well. 
Appearance: No head, hazy amber colour. 
Flavour: Caramel, jam, syrupy, alcohol and a distinct bitterness that kicks in after the initial thick maltiness has started to subside, ending in a warming finish. 
Mouthfeel: small lively bubbles and a thick mouthfeel
Total: This is very good and a perfect way to celebrate my birthday.

2011 White Wax Bottle; First - I had this on tap this year - a growler pour actually, from the brewpub. It was great, dont get me wrong, but I knew it was missing something so I didnt want to bother reviewing it. My instincts were correct ; the bottle - much better. Amazing actually - And yes, this brew works better as is, in comparison to the Barrel aged version. With that said - Pour is dark cloudy copper with amber highlights. Light beige head - Sweet caramel and typical delicious heavy hopped aromas typical of a FFF brew. This brew has a nice palatability for a barley wine. Grapefruit rinds, piney hops, caramel, toffee, molasses, and a light alcoholic note. Its sticky sweet - Well. Its the best barley wine ive sampled thus far , discounting barrel aged brews.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 Really boozy nose with some figs and caramel.  A bit of citrus shines through.  Sweet, with a lot of alcohol and that citrus hop bitterness.  Very intense, hard to drink in quantity even with a year of age.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2011 22 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp, pours a gorgeous dark mahogany with a small beige head. Marvelous aroma of dark dried fruits (raisins, cherries, figs, dates), some nuts, toffee, caramelized sugar, and a hint of molasses. Incredibly complex flavour - toffee and dried fruits begin initially, with burnt caramel, toasted nuts, a little smoke, pine, and a dark molasses finish, with only a tiny tingle of an alcohol burn (exceptionally well-worked in for 12%). This is a masterpiece of beer. Thanks so much for the opportunity to try this, Dany!
2009 version, courtesy of a friend at the Sexy Chocolate release 2011. Sweet, caramel aroma, no real hoppiness, smooth, very nice.

(22oz bottle courtesy of alpar. 2010 bottle!).  Pours mahogany, hazy and off-white head).  Aroma of hopfunk, alcohol and some pine. Taste is sweet with some alcohol burn. Slightly bitter in the end.  Medium bodied with sticky texture.  A hot, but excellent barleywine.

Sampled at the Richmond Gather XIII.  2007.  Very awesome. Hazy dark amber with big bubble fish eye tannish head. Still has a boatload of hops on it. Great sweetness and mellow alcohol.  Awesome american barleywine.
Red brown color with a fair amount of haze.  Sweet malty aroma. Flavor is sweet and malty.  Sweet caramel and maybe a hin of oxidation.

Yellow wax - 2007, 22 oz bottle from EithCubes. Pours deep copper with a small beige head. Aroma of dark, dried fruits, caramel, bread, booze and some light citrus. The flavor is mostly on the sweet side... dates, caramel and very malty, there is a light bitterness and very light alcohol warming. Medium to full body with mild carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. Lots of rich, sweet malt in this one, the hops have pretty much vanished. Light oxidization but doesnt detract too much from the flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2011 FULL VERTICAL TASTING
651mL 2005 pink wax. Somehow this has held up extremely well and is by far the best of the flight. The pour, like almost all the Behemoths is not very impressive- clear, deep amber with a thinning, yellow head that sticks around very little. Aroma on the 2005 is wicked though: extreme English toffee, old English barleywine cellar notes like a Thomas Hardy. Must, cellar, port vinous character. Spicy caramel, spicy wood, and red fruits come into play as well. Excellent creamy mouthfeel. Still so much balancing spicy hops. This could age for another year or more. incredible. 8/4/8/5/16=4.1
651mL 2007 yellow wax courtesy of pittsburghkid. The 2007 is more bitter, chalky, and has dark chocolate and cocoa powder rather than English toffee and old barleywine character. It also pours a little bit lighter than the rest of the vertical. This vintage has devolved into the classic "mint" aroma and profile that seems to plague American barleywines. Ive seen this in Doggie Claws and Third Coast Old Ale among others where orange mint and fresh mint dominate the nose and body.
651mL 2008 purple wax courtesy of dpjuart. This one is fruity, almost fruit juicy, sweet. Just straight cherry and apple juice box. Probably the worst of the bunch. 
651mL 2009 teal wax. Poured with the best carbonation but lower SRM. The high carbonation here actually detracts a little, and the body is too dry and chalky. Flavors are spicy, boozy, sweet. 
651mL 2010 green wax courtesy of pittsburghkid. More red fruits, sweet and spicy, nice warming alcohol that is retrained. Probably the next best of the vertical. 
651mL 2011 white wax thanks to TheTomG. Pour is phenomenal: clear red ruby with a massive, yellow, creme head with infinite retention and giant sheety lace. Aroma is raspberry tea, raspberry lemonade, toffee, orange mint, plums, apricot skins, sharp brandy alcohol. Taste is massively soft with just an incredible palate: pillowy carbonation and sharp, fresh mouthfeel. Perfect palate. Taste is fruity Valencia orange, fresh citrus, very fruity and juicy, sweet grapefruit, plums, lycee. Muted, nice spicy alcohol creates depth and reminds you this is some serious business. 8/5/8/5/16=4.2
Conclusion: I would say overall that Behemoth is not the best barleywine to age as the freshest vintage was best but the 2005 has miraculously turned into something quite incredible. Very different and more barleywine like where the fresh 2011 is more like a well done DIPA.
Red tinted clear brown pour with a light tan head.  Toasted grain aroma with caramel, and bitter roast.  Lightly sweet with biscuit and caramel.  Toasted malt with fruit, apple and bitter finish.

Highlight of the evening for sure. Bottle from Crackedkettle. Poured murky, with a ruby-copper color and a small, tan, lacing head. Cinnamon, honey, caramel, tons of hops, brown sugar, dark fruits, citrus, pine, and interestingly cantaloupe. Dense like a meal, with medium carbonation. This is an excellent one!

Bomber, courtesy of and shared with Balazs, thanks!
Cloudy coppery-mahagony coloured beer with a small creamy tan head. Cinnamon and honey, huge ammount of herbal hops, caramel and citrusses, resin and chestnut. Balanced, spicey and fruity aromachaos. Oily body with a well rounded, powerful flavor profile. Caramel and malt brings the base, very complex taste with fruits like fig, raisins and cantalope, honey. Spicies like cinnamon and vanilla, toffee. Herbal resiny hop on the tongue, fine balanced aftertaste

22oz bottle (2007) from wavers1, thanks, 
Appearance: Pours slightly cloudy dark amber with a medium sized beige head and good lacing 
Aroma: Sweet malts, caramel and brown sugar  
Taste: Sweet malts, brown sugar, citrus 
A great barley wine.

From notes 02/2010. Ive had this from the bottle a few times, but preferred it fresh on tap. Enjoyed at Finchs in Bloomington, IN.

Pours a cadmium orange, with almost burgundy hues into a snifter. A one finger khaki head leaves nice lacing as I get through the glass.

Beautiful, vibrant pineapple, grapefruit rind, heavy resinous hops, and burnt caramel. Heavy hop aroma on the nose. BBB is big. Barleywines are hit-or-miss for me and this one is killer. Sweet, fresh fruit meets sweet, caramel malts, and it finishes bitter and dry because of the pinesolesque resins. Something like maraschino cherries flies lowly in the taste profile. 

Sticky, sappy and sweet. Not cloying. 

This is one of the best beers I wager Ive had. Just a great amalgamation of rich flavors, an over-the-top floral and piney nose, and minimal carbonation make this an exceptional barleywine. It may not be everyones cup of tea, but I wish it were mine more often.

22oz bottle. 2009 version. Pours a copper/reddish color with a dense beige head. Good lacing and long lasting foam. Aroma is stunning: huge hoppiness altogether with a warm brandy-malty-caramelly aroma. Taste is huge and complex: piney bitterness, alcohol heat, caramel and fruits sweetness, wonderful. Finish is almost dry and bitter. Palate is full and soft with a good amount of carbonation.

Thank you drfabulous for this one. And wow. This is the 2008 release, aged two years. By far the best Barleywine Ive ever had. The citrus and caramel intermingle perfectly in the aroma. The taste is perfectly balanced and it is incredibly smooth. The beer also somehow manages to be both light and substantive at the same time. Savor this one if you can get your hands on it.

Bottle shared with jerc & mabel - Dec 22/08. Purple wax (2008) edition. Ruby-orange with a medium sized off-white head. Aroma - hops and booze! - plus caramel, grapefruit, candied citrus peel, nice! Flavour is big as hell, but amazingly will balanced, with notes of sweet orange, toffee, cherry, floral and citric hops, and a finish that is pleasantly warm but not as hot as it could be. Really nice stuff!
Shared bottle courtesy of gunnar. Clear orange with a white film. Caramel and dried fruits on the nose (sultanas stands out). Sweet, alcoholic and bitter. Full bodied with an oily texture.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 08 bottle from Santa a year+ ago.  Pours a semi-murky copper/red with a slick of off-white foam.  Aroma is thick, sweet malt, honey, caramel, and deep, sweet raisin.  Taste is sweet and balanced malt, honey, raisin, and the slightest edge of bitterness toward the finish (perhaps the long ago faded hops).  Aroma and taste are very well balanced.  This bottle aged very well and even though the hops are long gone this is an outstanding, easy drinking high ABV barley wine.

Wow - yellow wax aged 3 years, thank you friends in my beer community! It did not lose anything with aging, that is for sure. The barleywine pours amber syrup color, clear with a small head. The aroma of a typical sweet, malty syrupy barleywine that defines this style. On top of that sticky sweet resiny flavor is a bit of hoppiness. The ending is quite potent with a boozy bite on your heel.

Pours a beautiful ruby copper with a nice off white head. The smell of glorious hops immediately hits you and you know this is a barleywine of the American variety. The smell fades into some red fruits and sweet malt. The taste goes the same way, with the hops dancing in the forefront behind a pretty good malt base (I only say pretty good, as Im not a big fan of aged Behemoth--it loses the hops and the malt isnt complex enough, IMO). The mouthfeel is full and lucious, and although this is a sipper, Im always wanting another.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 09-24-2009

2008 vintage.  Pours hazy amber with a thin film head.  Nose is caramel malts and and American citrus hops.  Taste is strong liquid bready malts, caramel, toffee, and citrus hops.  Taste is less intense in malt extremes and hop extremes than others and seems extremely balanced.  Sweet and slick and sticky but still bitter in the finish.  Very good and balanced.

Appearance: amber orange. Huge pithy coppery head fades in rocky volcanic eruptions. Already sticking to the sides. Lace galore.

Nose: hops all over thought not overpoweringly so. Sap and hop resins with whole hop leafs. Wood underneath; pine bark, pine trees. Melba and apple crunchies.

Palate: sweet underneath with the lips relishing in fresh honey and honeycomb. Bitterness from hops come through underneath. An explosion of flavors atop my tongue. Apples and apple juice sweetness freshly squeezed with no added sugars. Resinous finish in back of throat with hop resins and pine sap. Balanced. Melba underneath mingles with honeycomb and apple skins.

Final Thoughts: whats not to love? An excellent Barleywine which balanced hops and malts with tasteful aplomb. Definitely worth a revisit or ten.

22 oz. bottle from The Party Source.  Green wax, 2010 vintage.  Pours a mostly clear amber color with a small eggshell white head.  Notes of caramel malts, brown sugar, raisins, sweet bread, wood, and some cardboard, almost as if this were older and has oxidized a bit.  The flavor and aroma are pretty similar.  I should have tried this fresh to get some hops, because they were mostly gone from this one.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a malty mouthfeel.  Good barleywine, but didnt quite meet my expectations.

650 ML bottle, 2010 Blue Wax - Pours deep caramel, thin 1/2 finger tan head.  Huge bouquet, more than words can describe.  Huge beer, biggest beer Ive ever had.  Such complexity, such flavor!!  Marvelous!
65cl, Edition 2009 (Blue wax), exclusive American brew, thx to Wimenels!, complex brew, heavy, yet balanced, cloudy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

2008 purple wax bottle, courtesy StFun. Pours a cloudy, bright golden orange color topped by a small, bubbly tan colored head of foam that quickly receds leaving spotty lacing behind on the glass. The aroma is really nice showing ample fruit character of oranges, grapefruits, and peaches from the citrus hops. Dark caramel, toffee, and vanilla comprise the malt base. There is just hint of booze as well to let you know it is there. The flavor is just as big as the nose foreshadows with tons of rich caramel, nougat, toffee, and vanilla followed by ample citrus hop bitterness of the orange and grapefruit variety. The age has mellowed out the hop bitterness for sure so the malt sweetness really comes through. As it warms up the alcohol starts to push through since the hop bitterness isnt there to mask it. Full bodied and smooth with ample carbonation that leads to a lengthy, sweet finish with some nice warmth from the alcohol. Great tasting barley wine that hides the high alcohol pretty well. I would love to try this fresh so I could get the full compliment of flavors from the hops.

2009 bottle from Ølbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours light amber with a tiny off-white head. Aroma is sweet grainy malts, sultanas and fruity hops. Taste a good moderate sweet, caramel and a good portion of fruity hops. Thick mouthfeel. Nice bitter finish

2007, yellow waxed bomber courtesy of TJBurgess on BA. thanks, TJ! pours an imposing, very murky, dark orange with a thin, whispy, off-white head and a tight, sticky ring of lace. aroma is wonderful with bold, spicy, piney hops, rich orange citrus, traces of tropical fruit, and hints of poached peaches backed by sweet, toasted caramel, honey, and toffee with a unique note of yeasty, cinnamon-raisin bread. flavor is delicious as well with loads of pine esters, orange citrus, and dried apricots up front backed by smooth, sweet caramel, nutty toffee, and rye bread with a wonderful, sweet, toasted malt finish. palate is full bodied but not the least bit cloying with a pleasant, warming sensation on the swallow and smooth carbonation. overall, an awesome barleywine with a few years on it. would love to try this one uber-fresh.

2009 - Looks like grey wax to me. The aroma is some hops, caramel, smells great. Pours a cloudy golden orange/copper with a creamy white head, mostly diminishing but not quite. The taste is bitter, sweet and a little sour. The body is medium to full, the texture creamy, the carbonation soft and the finish kinda bitter. Very good!

Bottle, vintage 2009, kindly shared by gunnar. Amber to orange colour, low head. Nice aroma of sultanas and dark dried fruits. The flavour has also notes of raisins, sweet malts, alcohol and decent hops.

Nutty, almost burnt caramel nose with some dried fruit.  Warm alcohol in the throat, this one is heavy on the abv and you can taste it. Great color and a suberb tasting beer, maybe a little to much alcohol for my tastes.
Bottle from a generous trader. 2009 vintage. Pours clear brown. Nose and taste of molasses, brown sugar, light bourbon, caramel malts and spiced citrus.
Pours a deep orange with no head, nose is caramel and peaches, taste is smooth, toffee, mild heat, and caramel

22oz bottle (2010) in a snifter.  Pours opaque light brown with a thin, beige head.  Bottle had been skunked, so I dont know about the aroma.  The flavor of sweet malts, strong hoppiness, and a little alcohol on the finish.  A great barley wine.

Yellow wax means 2007. 
Pours an orange color with a small head and some lace. The aroma is orange marmalade with a nice sort of dirty fruity aroma along with some toffee and caramel. The flavor is nicely roasty with some orange and some sherry with a nice light hop bitterness still sticking around. Pretty tasty. The palate is full and the carbonation is mild but noticeable.

2009 bottle, blue wax

caramel, nuts, resin, cheese, alcohol aroma
red, brown, clear appeareance
medium sweetness
medium body, thin feel, soft carbonation, long finish

A very good barley wine. clear and marsala alike

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 2010 vintage.  Chilled, but let this one warm up a bit.  Color is a mix of deep amber red mixed with apricot.  Light carbonation with minimal head, but persists.  Great earthy hop presence in the nose, a hallmark of 3 Floyds.  Also dried fruit, toasted malts, but the hops do it for me.  Full palate, like jello.  Extremely well-rounded and smooth - dried fruit, toasted malt, and wood.  Finishes dry with earthy/piney hops that linger.  Some alcohol presence, but not in the taste.  For me the hop presence definitely edges other barley wines Ive tried.  Now its time to pick up another bottle and let it sit for a few years!  Re-rate: multiple newer vintages.  Another very good American-style barley wine with traditional FFF hop presence.  Difficult price point for return.  Reality rate -0.5

Bottle thanks to Phaleslu!!! Shared with many appreciators. Deep, slightly hazed amber pour with a thin and creamy beige cap. This beer has the biggest nose I have ever experienced! It drips with fruitiness. From mango, to peaches, to apricot, to pear. Also in the nose, bready caramel malts some alcohol, and a massive amount of hops. But it is the tropical fruit note that makes this really special! Tastes as I expected. Loads of fresh tropical fruit like mango, melon, and other fruits, piney bitter hops balance perfectly, and lead to sweet caramel towards the finish, with the alcohol not all that detectable.  Chewy, resiny finish with loads of tropical fruit and lingering bitterness. One of the best beers I have ever had. Thanks so much Peter!!!

On tap at FFFs. Dark orange in appearance. Citrus and carmel nose, a perfect mix of yummy goodness. Tastes just like it smells, carmel/citrus/hoppy. Medium on the mouth, very smooth. This beer is easy to drink but will sneak up on you if youre not careful. Always have a few bombers on-hand while theyre available.

Three Floyds never disappoints, especially with this one. One of the most balanced barley wines I have ever had. Overall aroma of caramel, slight bitter finish but in no way offensive. The price of this had me skeptical but this brew didnt let me down in any way.

08 courtesy of gcurlow, thanks! nice very hazy amber pour with nice sheeting. the aroma is very nice, very sweet and malty, but still balanced. the taste is similar, still lots of bittering hops and even some aramatics, and a nice smooth rich malt body that goes down very easily. the palate is superb, light oily aftertaste leaves you wanting another sip.
2010 Bottle. Straightforward balance sweet caramel and hoppy bitterness. Great beer.

2008 bottle.  Rusty orange pour with a small white head.  Intense caramel aroma with bright orange and mixed citrus notes.  The flavor follows through from the aroma.  This is a big caramely malt bomb but in a delicious way.  The some peppery phenol bite on the end.  Creamy full body with soft carbonation.  This didnt come off very complex like I like most of my barley wines, but it was still delicious.

Yellow wax bottle.  Cloudy cola color with thin brief off-white head.  Aroma sweet/sour caramel, fruits.  Taste sweet malts, fruits, caramel with a hoppy finish that crescendos then ends abruptly.  Palate thick and syrupy.  Alcohol subtle.

An in-your-face beer but quite enjoyable.

Are you kidding me?!?! some dude brought the 05 to a bw tasting and left it in my fridge. dark burnt caramel chewy oaky nose. dark sludgy ruby. sweet and gentle, somewhat peaty, rosy earthy middle, growing heat in the finish plateaus rather than peaks

Flaske: Mørk ravfarvet øl. Klar med et fint skumhoved. Rigtig god karbonation i forhold til alkohol og stil. Fantastisk duft af humle og karamelmalt. Smagen sidder lige i skabet masser af sødme bakket op af en solid dosis humle. Ikke mærkeligt at Three Floyds er så berømmet. Fantastisk øl.

Latest ( green wax 2010 ) edition. Poured with a fine, smallish, light tan to cream colored head and a little lace. Color is a clear, copper amber. Aroma isnt too complex - massively malty and hoppy. Flavor is similar which is aka bittersweet. Good body and fine carbonation. Fairly long finish that is like flavor. Despite massiveness and strength (dont really pick up much alcohol) of this beer, could almost qualify it as a session.

Brewed in 2006!?  Yellow wax on a 22 oz bottle.  Small quickly fading head.  Huge nose on this one, sweet caramel, dried fruit.  Strong rush of hop bitterness with a big creamy, caramel body, excellent carbonation, very intense but not harsh. This beer has aged very nicely, and is very smooth. Long finish, slowly turns from hoppy to sweet. Alcohol is very well hidden as well.  Excellent beer, not surprising coming from Three Floyds.

Blue wax tasted from 22oz bottle at Lush Roscoe.  The pour is clear amber with a fairly thin white head that leaves light lace around the glass.  Nose of sweet caramel malt with citrus and herbal hops and some oxidative nuttiness.  The hops really take over on the palate leaving the sweetness and malts on the back burner.  The body is full with light carbonation and a long caramelized and super hoppy finish.
GREAT GREAT GREAT.  Dark Red color with huge hoppy aroma.  Big sweet and full body.  Really great stuff.  I dont usually like sweet, but I loved this.  Get some if you can.

2008 Bottle: Pours a cloudy copperish orange with a thin off-white head that leaves excellent lacing. Has a sweet malty aroma with hints of caramel and some spices. Flavor is sweet with hints of caramel and dried fruits. Texture is creamy with a mild tangy bitter finish. Easy drinking and the alcohol was very well hidden for 12%. I didnt realize I liked Barley Wines so much. This was delcious!

2010 bottle.  I would not qualify this as a barley wine, this seemed like a DIPA through and through.  Poured a deep orange with an off-white head.  Aroma was citrus hops, huge malt nose, pine resin, grapefruit..  Flavor was big and sweet, caramel, toffee, but also very resiny, and citrus.  Big hop character.  Good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2011 2010 Vintage.  Sampled at the 3 Floyds event at the Brickskeller.  Pours a clear, copper amber with a very frothy, off white head.  Metallic aroma, biscuit dough, C hops, a little rank, tropical fruits.  Flavor is sweet, butterscotch, oranges, caramel, candy, sticky fruits, a little bread, mango.  Full bodied and bitter.  Id had aged versions before, and Id say this wasnt my favorite barleywine when fresh.  ******Re-rate of a complete vertical in January 2011.  2005 bottle was oxidized, had a great leathery nose and plenty of raisin and sherry in the flavor.  My favorite vintage.  2007 bottle had more caramel and a little bit of wood in the nose and flavor.  Third best.  the 2008 bottle had lots of fading citrus, mint, citrus peel, oranges.  4th best.  2009 bottle had lots of grapefruit and the alcohol was a little overwhelming of the flavor.  Worst of the bunch.  2010 batch had bright hops, lemon and a touch more malt than the others.  2nd best batch.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle.

This is beer No. 1499. The beer pours red-amber with a medium off-white head. The aroma is caramel malt and citrus hops. The flavor is caramel malt with a nice mix of orange and piney hops. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation. A very nice barleywine.

from crackedkettle.com - pours a hazy red-orange colour with a little beige foam left; nice aroma of caramel and prune, fairly hoppy with notes of quince marmalade; thick and full-bodied, moderate carbonation, a solid bitterness and a long fruity hoppy finish with notes of warming alcohol and piney hops

5/22/10.  Bomber (green wax, must be 2010) into a snifter.  The pour is a glowing amber/red with a 1.5-finger off-white fluffy head that fades pretty quickly and laces a tiny bit.  The aroma is noticeably huge American hops - sweet, citrus, floral, and yummy.  This mixes really well with the underlying sweetness - caramel and more.  The flavor is noticeably hoppy at first, both with nice hop flavor and a touch of bitterness, which transitions into wonderful dark fruits and sweet caramel and ends dry and hoppy, making you crave the next sip even more.  Definitely an American barleywine.  Yum hops.

acquired in trade - 22 oz. bottle into a snifter
Pours a mahogany red with a smallish head which completely disappeared. Very light lacing which didnt last. Nose is ripe cherries, bananas and butterscotch. Hoppy start gave way to dark fruit, esp. cherries, banana and butterscotch. It almost tastes like a lighter sherry. There is a little hop bitterness in the dry finish. Some alcohol warming is there, but less that the 12.5% might lead you to expect. The mouthfeel is creamy but light for the style. This was an OK barleywine but not a favorite.
thanks to Hophead22 for the tasting.From a 22oz bottle,brown in color,sweet barley wine which is not a bad thing,white head.
22 ounce bomber shared-brown orange pour-tan head-aroma and taste of caramel, roasty, nuts,dough, earthy, pine -nice hoppy finish

2008 bottle  - Rich thick barley wine with a great aroma thick with malt and spices.  The alcohol was present but did not over take.  This was a great sipping beer.  Perfect for that cold night.  When this warms up the flavors explode and come alive the spices, and dried fruit flavors where very nice.

Boulder Strong Fest at Avery. Amber with red hue, off white head that lasts, very lacy. Aroma is blast of sweet ripe fruit, citrus notes, light alcohol, caramel. Taste is syrupy sweet fruit going into boozy bitter finish that burns going down. Light oily palate. Outstanding barleywine, not too sweet.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2010 On tap @ the Bavarian Lodge. Poured a dark amber with a medium sized, off white head that settled quickly, but could easily be revived with quick swirl. The aroma at first was new leather and a bit of dark fruit, with some caramel. As it warmed, green apple, pine,  and citrus came through. The flavor had a lot of the same chacteristics, but was both more caramel and hops. The finish was a pretty well balanced mix of sweet and bitter. Awesome BW.

very sweet, rich complex malt, lots of citrusy hops (especially for a barleywine - the hoppiest barleywine ive had (@500)). a deffinite "wow" beer, but not because its crazy and mean, just because its big and wonderful.  way too easy to drink, considering the 12% side-effects.

Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Green Wax 2010 vintage. I really wanted to try a fresh bottle with lots of hops. Pours dark brownish color with tan head. Typical 3 Floyds huge hop aroma with some maltiness. Juicy hop flavor with lots of sweet maltiness. Medium to full body with average carbonation. Excellent! Thanks Peter.

orangey red cloudy color, aroma is big floral hoppiness, flavor is sweet smooth and bitter, like a big pale ale. Not as much malt as I expected. Id call this an american Strong Ale, like a Double Bastard. Bottle from a tasting with Smith4498, Legato, and Cbeers21.

pretty sure it was an 08.. Sweet maple syrup, dark honey, and dipped pinecone .. pours a light caramel-red colour .. Super mellow stuff! .. wheres the abv? i drank this way to fast, i just disappeared!!.. . just awesome! .. . One morning I shot an elephant in my pajamas. How he got into my pajamas Ill never know..
Bottle (2009 release): pours an orangish brown with a thin white head, aroma is hoppy and sweet, taste is malty, sweet, mild hop bite, full bodied, nice

22oz bottle, 2007 release.   Hazy red-brown with a small head.   The aroma has a rich caramel quality with some ginger and pine spice and a touch of sherry-ish oxidation.   The flavor has the same ginger touch with plenty of rich caramel and malt.   Still pretty bitter and hot in the finish, though it does show a touch of aged, oxidized quality.   Full bodied and pretty smooth.   Interesting stuff, but I think it might have been better a couple years ago.

2006 Vintage. Pours dark amber with an off white head. Bold aroma of caramel and fruity ale esters. Full bodied with soft to medium carbonation and a very slight sticky texture. The hops are pretty faded on this, but it brings out pleasant caramel, sherry, and brown sugar flavors. Warming finish, but no unpleasant alcohol flavors. I need to try a fresh version to get more bitterness.

2009 vintage. Poured a nice burnished copper color with a nice collar of off white foam.

Sweet aromas of grapefruit, honey and green apples.

The flavor of this one is an incredible mixture of honey, bubble gum, peaches and canned pears, all of which combine to almost completely hide the loads of alcohol contained within, before finally leading to a nice bitter, drying finish.

I traded for this one as an afterthought in a big trade, and I am very glad I did. A very nicely balanced barley wine, easy to drink and thoroughly enjoyable.

Purple wax.  Pours clear dark amber color with off white head.  Aroma is sweet caramel, some hop, that twang barleywine smell.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor follows the nose and finishes semi sweet.  A really nice barleywine for the style.

09. Pours dark amber with thin ivory head. Nice lacing for a BW. Aroma of malt, brown sugar, resin, and caramel. Alcohol is very well masked; body is very balanced. Taste of caramel, malt and pine. Smooth, soft finish. Probably the best non-cellared BW Ive tried. Well done FFF.

Bottle of the yellow waxed 2007. The appearance is a crystal clear deep cherry read with a small light-tan to white head and some small tight bubbles. The aromas are sweet with florals, complex malts, fruity resins, caramel, some earthy hops. Flavors are strong with malts, nice fruit flavors lightly bitter apples, caramel, a moderate alcohol presence, nice hop bitterness that comes through even more at the end!. An excellent American Barleywine

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2010 On tap at barley island in BR.  Nose is lots of hops. Pours golden amber with thin white head. Lots of hops with a characteristic sweetness that comes with barley wines.  Thick and syrupy mouthfeel that goes down nicely. A very good barely wine, if a little generic.

On tap at Barley Island in Broad Ripple...great find! Pours relatively clear reddish/brown with minimal head. Nose and flavors are citrus hops, sweet/fruity malt, slight alcohol burn and a well rounding winelike character. Probably the most hops Ive tasted in a B.W., but Ive come to expect that from all of FFF beers, and I cant complain.

22oz bottle from 2009. Pours rusty brown with a small tan head. Nice tan lacing lasts for most of the beers life. Moderate carbonation. Aroma is of hops, caramel, malt, alcohol, grass, and sugar. Typical Three Floyds hop character present in the aroma. Taste starts off with some very earthy hops and raisins. Strong base of caramel malt balances out the earthy hops nicely. The alcohol is very well hidden, but provides a nice warming effect. Thick, malty mouthfeel. Has a lingering boozy earth taste to it. Drinks way too easy for what it is. As it warms, a lot of caramel starts to become noticeable. Not sure why it took me this long to rate it. Its solid.

This is a 2010 Green Wax Bottle.  Pours amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is pine, sweet carmel and alcohol.  The taste sensation is pretty cool.  It seems to fluctuate between bitter pine hops and very sweet carmel before finally settling on a bitter hops aftertaste.  Nice warming sensation with very little alcohol taste.  Another big win from 3 Floyds!

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2012 (Re-rate, bottle, 2009 vintage - 0.65 l, at Pikkulintu, 20121115) The beer poured deep amber and clear. Its head was small and white. Aroma had raisins, dried plum, malts and sweetness. Palate was full bodied and quite dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were raisins, malts, dried plum, dark fruits, sweetness and bitterness. Aftertaste had raisins, malts and bitterness. Aging had improved this beer noticeably.

(Bottle, 2009 vintage, at Maltainen Riekko) Poured deep amber and almost clear with small and white head. Aroma contained fruitiness, malts, molasses and alcohol. Palate was medium bodied with low carbonation. Flavours were malts, hops, mild roastedness, saltiness, alcohol, pine and mild bitterness. Aftertaste was malty and bitter. Old rating: 8-4-7-3-14=3.6

Bottle from free table at Woodshop 5.0. Pours a clear orange-gold with a thin off-white froth. Aromas of caramel and alcohol, raisins, fruity hops. Flavor is fruity with a lot of caramel and the a bitter homage to the hops that used to be in this beer (Im guessing it was a vintage bottle). Very full body, sweet and thick and bitter. Good beer.

2009 bottle.  Pours a slightly lacing beige head with an amber body.  Aromas of brown sugar, citrus and pine notes, and biscuits.  Flavor can be described much like the aroma, a cocoa note.  Finish is bitter and dry, sticky.

2009 bottle. Pours deep crimson brown. Smells fantastic. Just like a braley wine is supposed to smell like. Caramel, sweet malt, cinnamon, lush. Tastes of sweet alcohol, maple syrup, velvety smooth. Hops presence is very muted. This is a malt driven barley wine.  Sweet, smooth, and delicious. The hops presence is there just enough, especially on the finish. Great beer.

2010 edition.  Green Wax.  Yet another delicious example of Three Floyds mastering a style of beer and creating their own unique twist to it.  Pours a copper brown.  Great head that remains until the end.  Excellent lacing.  Aroma is a blast of caramel malts with a variety of fruits (grapefruit, apricot, peach).  Taste is absolutely amazing.  Not as thick as your typical barley wine, but packed with Three Floyds trademark crystal hops, caramel, and a fantastic citrus note from the fruits.  Amarillo hops and the fruits create an outstanding citrus element that balances out the malts and barley.  The flavors and potency of this beer increases dramatically as it warms.  Even though this dances on the edge of a double IPA, this is probably the most enjoyable barley wine Ive ever had.  $14 for a 22oz is a bit steep, but Three Floyds has yet to disappoint me with their brilliant creations. and is easily my favorite brewery.  See you all at Dark Lord day.

In the Book of Job 40:15-24, the Behemoth is described as the largest and most powerful animal ever to exist. Thats one hell of a name to live up to! Will this beer follow with such dominance of its own? Its a big call but at the end of the day its only a name on a label right? And whats the deal with that label anyways? Im sure it was designed on purpose to play tricks on the minds of unassuming beer geeks. I mean how many guys have been caught out gazing at the label in lust after imbibing more than a bottle or two. Unowhadimean. How did Miss Behemoth suddenly transform into Miss Estonia gracing the label. A reliable gauge for knowing when to call it a night me thinks. Three Floyds have seriously unleashed a beast of its own with the Behemoth Barley Wine. Pours dark amber with a head that slowly retreated to a thin lace. Welcoming aroma of raisiny malt, licorice, caramel and delicate floral hop notes. The hops shine through even more in the flavour and as it warms up it takes on a real change in character. Heaps of grapefruit, tangerine, apricot, plums and caramel malt sweetness. All really good stuff. Smooth mouthfeel and great balance. The abv is well masked and at no point overwhelming - just the slightest hint of warming in the finish. This ones a real treat. Good on ya Jase for sharing another gem. Bottle (2009 Blue Wax).

Not normally a barley wine fan but this was a very good example. Nose was lots of apricot, bubblegum, thick toffee and pine. In the mouth it is viscous with a big caramel, honey, apricot and bubblegum body with a sharp spray of citric and piney hops. Well made and well balanced. Thanks to Volcanicbeat for this.
