Aroma is a tale of subtle glory.  Matured black cherries, raspberry fig chews, rosebuds, red and black currant mix, deep amaretto, black raspberry seeds, boysenberries and a tiny hint of alcohol.  Lord is this flavor smooth.  The epitome of an aged barleywine, upstaging Third Coast Old Ale and Old Horizontal.  Ripe cream cheese qualities allude to raspberry cheesecake.  More chewy than the fresh bottled batch.  My wife would be revolted by my palate chomping.  Patronizes the notion of a balanced equilibrium.  Sticky malts and a supportive hop backdrop couldnt form a more symbiotic relationship.  Finishes like a raspberry cream cheese danish and almond butter laden with juniper berries, free from all jovial qualities.  Ill be damned.  This was the Dr. Jekyll; the bomber was Mr. Hyde.
2005 bomber all to myself - fresh, October 2005.Semi-syrupy pour to a translucent brass color, seemingly filtered, but with good reason.  Dusty tan bubbles for the head and sexy legs on the side of my snifter throughout all 22-ounces of bliss.  This is one hell of a nose: lavender, strawberries, grapefruit, star fruit, cherry cheesecake, amarillo and brown sugar.  Flavor is a wham-bam bitch slap, and I turn the other cheek.  Amaretto, cherry juice and liquefied brown sugar register first.  My taste buds play host to a citric floral conference (pineapple, grapefruit and papaya.)  Throw in a touch of cooking sherry for good measure and now the complexities are innumerable.  Bitterness resounds while a caramel cadence drums up the malt support.  Vinous, oozing and dehydrating, making me reach for more more more.  The balancing act couldnt be more harmonious - in fact, its perfect.  Bitter and comprehensive finish spurring an aftertaste of raspberry crepes basking in maple syrup.  Worth every penny, mile and minute to obtain.  God bless.

Bottle:  Courtesy of temporrari and JCW.  Very hoppy aroma.  Smells like an IIPA.  Aroma is loaded with citrus hops.  Pours a transparent reddish-orange with an insignificant white head that only forms a ring around the edge of the glass.  Like the aroma, tastes just like a IIPA.  Quick initial sweet orange flavor is almost instantly dominated by a huge citrus hop finish.  Very good, but needs some aging in order to resemble a Barley Wine as opposed to a IIPA.
Multi-dimensional sweet caramel malts, tempered expertly by both a generous dose of bitter hops and pervasive alcohol fumes...really too young to rate properly yet.  Talk to me in a year.

At the brewerys 2005 release:  The only "flaw" that I could find with this barleywine is that it was so young, so I picked up enough bottles to be rerating this as they age, starting with Nick Floyds recommended six month mark.  It poured a near headless golden brown.  The aroma is a sweet caramel/toffee malt, somewhat fruity, with a trace of alcohol and a light citric and pine hop scent. This is thick and warm in the mouth, a pleasure to savor before swallowing.  The flavor remains fruity (plums, cherries...) with caramel and butterscotch and alcohol and just a touch of hop bitterness.  The hops come forward more in the finish, but the sticky (and alcohol laden) malt sweetness dominates.  This is great stuff and it will be difficult to resist drinking some of the bottles that I intend to age.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Floyds Brewing Company, Munster, IN<font size=-1>

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2006 Now that Ive had the 2001 Behemoth that the Floyds "found" in the cooler and put on tap at the brewpub, I can discount my description below (and save my bottle of 2005 to age for a while). The draft pour is a deep cloudy brown, with a thin barleywine head. Bigass malts prevail in this one, with a bit of taffy apple-caramel sweetness. Alcohol is not heady or overpowering at first, but sneaks up big time toward the end. Theres a touch brandy, with a swirl of strawberry, prune and cherry. Very thick and chewy.
Bottled off kegging line by 3Fs employee. My rating is tempered by the fact that the sample was bottled 4 years ago and not counter-pressure filled. But I expect to have some fresher stuff when the bottles finally come out this summer. This sample was slightly cloudy. Not as hoppy as most 3Fs, just the remains of a fine hop bouquet. This is, yes, slightly oxidized, but also sweet and somewhat fruity, with a hint of raspberry.

Draft at Clarks Ale House in Syracuse...WHAT A FIND!  Fruity, malty aroma with hints of spice and citrus.  Moderately hazy amber color with a small light tan head.  Mmmm creamy maltiness hits the tongue to start...bam.  Fruity citrus ethanol burn follows with a nice little hop kick in the ass as this one goes down.  Gorgeous lacing too, I might add.

Draft at the brewery.  I think it was the end of last years keg.  Murky orange with a creamy tan head and a sharp hop nose (like all Three Floyds beers).  Caramel, butterscotch, plum liquer.  Very green hop finish.  Thick, syrupy mouthfeel.  Just plain delicious.
Brown color, with a malty scent. Tasted of malt, but was also vinous and a bit salty. Thick, but not so thick that it was hard to drink. Excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2005 Draft at brewery, so a bit hard to give an accurate rating. Decent head which sticks around. Brown/red body. Aroma has bubblegum, caramelly hops. Tastes "just damn good." A bit of citrusy hops and sweet with caramel. A bit syrupy on the palate, but also creamy and very slightly oily. I just updated palate to a "5" because I think I underrated that category in this and other beers... (8 / 4 / 9 / 5 / 18)

Rerate bottle 11-21-2005. Clear ruby body, very thin fizzy head. Strawberry-like flowery medicinal hops. The aroma is quite like I remember it, even though the terms have changed. Not as thick as I remember it though. Hoppy bubblegum. Dirty water finish. (8 / 5 / 8 / 4 / 17)

UPDATED: APR 20, 2004 Awesome brew!  I drank this out of a friggin' plastic cup at the brewery, so I couldn't see the body very well, but I'm pretty sure it was dark red.  The head was quite creamy with very small bubbles.  Small amount of caramel in the aroma along with the same hops featured in the flavor.  Syrupy, plummy, winey taste.  Gin-like hops with lemon citrus.

Draft at the brewery, aged one year.  Poured a murky brown color with a creamy yellowish off white head and nice lacing.  Strong citrus hop and caramel malt aroma.  Very rich mouthfeel had tastes of citrus and bitter hops, and well as being balanced by a nice sweet maltiness.
Truly amazing.  Very sweet and the aroma is very fruity.  Brown color with nice head.  Alcohol was somewhat noticable.  Definitely have to sip and savor the moment.
UPDATED: SEP 27, 2007 (Draught)  Pours a medium brown with a medium-sized beige head.  Had a wonderful array of fruit flavors and caramel. Alcohol was nicely covered by the abundant flavor.

Aroma:  sweet honey and strawberries.
Appearance:  light brown
Flavor:  strawberries and cream, with slight corn flavors when warmed. Also, vanilla yogurt and carmel malts.
Palate:  Very smooth with slight carbonation, like a very weak soda.
Overall an excellent barley wine, probably one of the better ones I have had.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 Draft @ brewery, Thanksgiving 2003 - Murky dark brown, aroma of strong, sweet berries and scotch.  Intensely punchy and strong... amazing representation of the style.  Thick, ravaging the mouth with scotch, pine, sweet maple, pears... perfect mouthfeel. rerate needed, but I dont trust the bottles.

Redbrown with thin beige head. Aroma dominated by Cascade hops and alcohol.
The flavour is sweet with tones of toffee and Cascade. Lots of alcohol.
Decent try

a very nice barnyard aroma, with a slightly buttery, perhaps cheesey taste in the front with some nice dark fruits coming through in the back, with a little bit of hop in the fatertaste and a very solid malty backbone.  Very dark and syrupy, with some extremely solid complexities.  I would like to have some more of this one.

UPDATED: DEC 31, 2003 I had one as part of my three beers at the 3Floyd's tour. This is fantastic. I could probably drink one throughout a week and still enjoy it. It's so strong too and the warmth it generated inside myself was anything, but that ugly behemoth as a mascot. I wish I had more than one. And I will, for some better notes.
Wow...what an incredible Barley wine.  Great flavor that improves markedly as the beer warms.  Beautiful coloration, a nice subtle hoppiness...excellent!

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 Re-rate 3/11/07. Bottle. Lovely, hoppy aroma. Beautiful, slightly hazy dark red. Tan head. Smooth. Hoppy. Strong, wonderful. Bite creeps up; subtle. Im a little surprised by its subtlety; hides the 12%. Great balance. Excellent. 8/26/03: Draught at GTM. Very rich, hoppy, bourbonish aroma. Reddish yellowish in color. Very attractive. Thick head. Small bubble. Incredibly attractive. Very rich, almost orgasmic. Extremeley good flavor. I had two of the best beers I have ever rated on the same day from the same 3 floyds tent at the Great Taste of the Midwest (3 Floyds Alpha King being the other). Ar 8, Ap 5, Fl 10, Pal 4, Ov 19.
Tap, FFF, Ratebeer Summer Party 2k3.  Big northwestern hop aroma.  Big caramel malt flavor.  Dryish finish.  Excellent.

Thanks to jcalabre for this one. My first thought was that it would go good poured over french toast. Very dark, thick sweet candy with enough kick to burn in it's impression all the way down. Somehow it all comes together to be enjoyable, though atypical of the style from my experience.
On tap at the brewery:  Light brown with a tan head.  Piney hops and alcohol aroma.  Sticky mouth feel ends really sweet.  Too sweet if you ask me.
(draft):  Black body with creamy small head.  Aroma is big hoppy -- herbal/floral.  Taste is sweet strong sticky, heavy malty, big hoppy, some herbal.  Sticky, extra-full body.

Hefty aroma, dripping with caramel, pine, flowers, spices and citrus.  Dark copper color with a very fine, creamy, uneven head.  Massive dosage of hops here and VERY sweet, thick, syrupy maltiness, more caramel and bitter, juicy, resinous hops.  Some balance is achieved although everything here is present in astounding quantities.  Long, lingering, bitter, alcoholic, spicy finish.  Would have been better had it not been served to me just a little too cold and in a cheap plastic cup.  You'd think the brewers would know better.
Rated at RB 2003. Thick creamy head, brownish. Sweet and juicy malts with hints of caramel. I found a bit too heavy. Vintage probably would taste better.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2005 Rerate 2002 batch: As aged wonderfully with a deep fruity and vinous quality. The hops are now subdued with the framework of the brew and it is a behemoth but more graceful that ever before...
Original review:
On tap at Brewery. Multicolored hue of red/brown/orange with a average sized head and good lacing. Full bodied. Breathtaking aroma of smoke, brown sugar, grapefruit, molasses, dark bread with a hint of roasted malt and nuts. Sweet taste with a moderate level of alcohol, smooth for a beer this big. Syrupy and soft mouthfeel. Im not the biggest fan of barleywine, this one could change my mind.
From the tap at the Brewery while picking up a keg of Dreadnaught. Sweet, Carmely, toffee, loads of dark juicy fruits.  A fantastic Barley Wine. moderate intese piney hops. Awsome, So Awsome

Visited the brewery this weekend to get my second keg of Dreadnaught.  They were out so I was offered a keg of Behemoth.  This is not an ordinary Three Floyds brew.  There is a hop nose, but very little hop in the flavor.  Flavor consists of caramel, raisins and alcohol.  Another great brew but this keg will last forever, it absolutley kicks you in the ass.  Thanks Three Floyds for the hangovers my wife and I will incur over the next few months.

Clear dark amber color.Light tan head that hangs as a small ring around the perimeter of my tasting glass.Piney, citrusy nose! Med/full body.Oily, slick mouthfeel. Large(almost Behemoth) citrusy hop flavors! Chinooks!? Big ass beer! Alc. making it presence known as it warms. Would age well. Do they bottle this yet? Thanks Belgianhomebrew!

Syrupy sweet, like their Alpha Klaus, even though they are different types of beer.  Somewhat hoppy.  Even smells awfully sweet.  Candy, raisins, and dried fruits - a hint of cocoa.  Apples and Pears...somewhat alcoholic finish, but it doesn't burn.

[draught]  This is one sticky f-in' barleywine - medium hop presence, like a cross between a west coast and east coast brew - vinous, with lots of fruits (cherries and strawberries in particular) - hops in the finish, and vinous notes as well, making for a very odd and not entirely enjoyable finish - still a great barleywine.
Nice rich body full of fruity malt aroma and intense flavors. Malt sweetness balances the alcohol and hops beatifully.
Friuty apple, citrus, dark fruit nose. Malty caramel and fruit taste with some hops added in. Creamy smooth mouthfeel. Fun stuff. Hopsrus to alcfron to me. Thanks.

A robust rusty dirt/clay feel to the color. Can not say much for the head as it did not make much of an appearance. Higher than I expected carbonation is the first noticable attribute. A nice spicey sweet aroma with borderline alcohol fumes. Tastes like a harmonic mixture of butterscotch, spice, citrus fruit and alcohol. Damn near impressive.

The warnings had been coming across the wires for the longest time, But I had paid them no heed. I wandered ahead into the darkness.  I sensed an enormous presence and my nostrils flared. I attempted a girlish shriek with the back of my wrist against my forehead, but the behemoth was upon me. I was completely overpowered. Okay, in all actuality I was more amazed at just how I wasn't overpowered. While this has strength in all its assets, they are so beautifully balanced that I could see myself drinking his all night long.Or at least as long as I could manage. Delicious! The syrupy caramel like malt taking volleys from  the wonderful hop bitterness. Hopsrus you done me right. Many thanks.
I've become a barleywine fan because of this beer. It has a definite alcohol kick, but is balanced by the smooth fruity flavor.

Perturbingly smooth drinking from my first three floyds brew. This one pours a cloudy reddish brown color with a tiny off white head, little if any. The aroma hints at sweetness, fruity esters, caramel malts, definite hops presence, and citrus. The taste is a beautiful amalgamation of smooth caramel malts..just perfectly sweet with a tiny bittering alcohol presence. Fruity orange and citrus undertones caress the palate. Little carbonation level, just perfect in almost every respect. Total aftertaste explosion in the mouth. An extremely nice barleywine!!!
LIKE A FRUIT FAIRY WALKING A TIGHT-ROPE MILES HIGH ABOVE COMPETING BARLEYWINES---A  PERFECT BALANCE BETWEEN CARAMEL MALT(S) SWEETNESS AND MASSIVE HOPS.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2003 I must say that I really enjoyed having my senses tickled, or massaged...literally all 5 senses took part. The soft exploding of bubbles was noted and I swear I saw a dove in the lacing. Amazing creamy & malty (Grape-Nuts soaked in 2% milk) aroma. The initial fruity goodness widened to a juicy caramel apple kiss. Sticky, chewy, vinous. Impressive carbonation.

Deep brown color with a medium beige head.  A bit if an alcohol taste, hints
of caramel and citrus fruit.

Thanks to hopsrus for sending me some of his stash of this (bottled from growler). Very dark maple syrup color with a medium beige head. Strong malt and caramel nose. Rich and full-bodied, consisting of flavors of malt, alcohol, caramel and pineapple. Nice tart hops presence in the finish. Excellent.

RAF: Dark copper in appearance.  Very bitter with an aggressive hop aroma.  Alcohol is evident.  Lots of hops in this one.  Pine, caramel, grapefruit/citrus masked by intense bitterness.  Very sweet.  More drinkable than other barleywines I've sampled, given its relatively young age.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2003 Fresh Draft: superbly subliminal gleaming intoxication of dark ruby red..a thin head above and aromas of cherries and grapefruits, smoke, and alcohol..the tongue is slapped with sticky pine resin, grapefruit rind, cherries, fruit cocktails, and beef jerkey...a delightful, dark-lit/late night sipper..and so freaking tasty it amazes me..although i suppose the hoppiness can get out of hand if your not in the mood for it.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 Hotstuff and I went on a tour of their brewery. For $5 you get a 12oz glass of 3 of their beers. I thought this was the worst of their beers. The aroma was obnoxious to me. The head was mixed with large and small bubbles. It had a heavy taste with an after bite and an initial taste that I could only describe as off. The color was very nice deep caramel brown and you could not see through it. GF did not rating it but preferred to get another Robert The Bruce instead!

Mmmmm... Barleywine!  Dark reddish black with a light head introduces you to this great barleywine.  The strong combination of flavors mask a high alcohol content.  So complex that it could take a life-time to figure out all the flavors on your own.  Goes down smooth and is the best sipping beer for a winter night.

Bottled from growler, thanks hopsrus!!
Clear red, small head. Very roasty hop aroma. Sweet and resiny. Softly malty, but still feels light, despite it's gravity. Flowery and citrusy. Syrupy bitter finish.

Dark red-brown color with a light haze - expectedly small head and light carbonation (appropriate to style).  Rich malt aroma with caramel and fruit (pear and fig), but mainly caramel, with peppery hops.  Full round sweetness and lip smacking lingering toffee like flavors.  Resiny and peppery hop flavors with a lingering mild bitterness.  Alcoholic strength is definitely apparent with a chest warming buzz, but generally speaking its well masked for an 11+% beer.  Beer becomes sticky and sweet, almost syrupy, towards the end - a bit unattractive in a barleywine, and indicative IMO of under-attenuation, perhaps the yeast pooped out in all that alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2003 Holy sweet malty hops!  The signature 3Floyds Hop pops in and out of this thick and candied mouthfeel reigning in any potential syrupiness.  The alcohol warms and gives this dessert beer a mature, port-like sensation.  A great beer to drink while pondering life.  Eddie G- thanks again!

Good red color along with a malty smell and underlying hop aroma.  Alcohol evident but still hidden pretty well for 11%.  Good sweet flavor that is still balanced with trademark 3 Floyds hop character.  I don't really consider myself a barley-wine fan but WOW, 3 Floyds has done a good job with this brew.  A must try.  Thanks again EddieG.

Super grapefruit aroma with a bit of cedar, resin, and salty malt. Vinous notes (concord grapes) alcohol, brown sugar, toffee come out on warm up. Sweet yams and brown sugar on the taste that finishes bitter and warm. Beautiful brew. Thank you hopsrus...

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2007 This beer MUST be allowed to warm to thouroughly enjoy what it has to offer.  Deep red with a cascading head as you pour.  Not shy with the hops but balanced superbly by a massive malt presence.  Toffee, pears and spruce come through in the flavor that stays with you for what seems to a whole day.
Great offering!!!

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2004 Mmmmm, let this one roll around in your mouth for awhile: so velvety smooth, warm hops along the sides of your tongue, thick sweetness down the middle.  When you finally swallow, feel the warmth travel slowly down your throat.  Finish is dry with some peppery hops.  This is #800 for me, on my first anniversary of rating here, I hope that I can find more beers of this quality in the future.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2005 (Hand-bottled from tap):
Vibrant hop vitality in this Bigfoot-like biosphere...Bounteous port-wine lagoons and blackberry groves garnish this pillowy resinous bedrock...A sweet cough syrup memento heralds youthful overexuberance...A wilderness adventure so rich and balanced that for the moment of the rendezvous, you might actually believe that hops can taste like berries...Many thanks once again to hopsrus...4.5/5

2005 bottle:
Voluminous raspberries and cranberries are candied to sweeten this fruity hop wine...Malt is slender (hope it doesnt hinder its aging potential), and carbonation is low even for the style...Alcohol burning fits with the resinous hops flavor and bitterness, but the rather thin mouthfeel makes the heat a little too obvious...A splendid effort, full of charisma, but maybe still too immature to yield masterpiece sagacity...4.1/5
Malty sweet aroma.  Body is slightly sweet, with a fair amount of hops, but balances the alcohol quite nicely.  Another great brew from 3 Floyds.

Burnt amber and crimson with a super tight head that apperated about 5 seconds after the pour and dissapeared....but still some how left laceing.  After swirling it a bit, the tan head reamerged in thick gloppy swaths reminicant of the condesed milk at the top of a Thai Ice tea.  The nose is something of beauty.  Upon opening this gem I was kicked in the nose with fresh  hops.  As it warmed more malt started to haze over the greenery with a winey nearly salty charactor evolving furthur into caramel, burnt sugar, and toffee.  The mouthfeel remains improbably thick and creamy, almost like fine grade maple syrup.  Stong nots of malt viniouness, citic hops (grapefruit) cadi sugar, black peppar, toffee, light alcohol, caramel.  Finish ligers for ever and cascades from wine to floral hops, to bread ending with more hops.  Comes across sweet and dry at the same time (not sure how).  Throughout all of this it still remains unbelievably smooth.  Absolutly stunning.  Thank you Psychprof.

What can I say other than this is the BEST BEER I have ever had. Now let me say that I drove an hour from Chicago to the brewrey to pick up some of 3 Floyds for the Super Bowl. I bought a growler of this barleywine and I feel in love (no I did not take it to the party, I am selfish). Now back to the beer; there may be better beers but I have never tried it. this one may get a boost from the fact that it did not sit on a boat from Europe for the last few months. Like a bouquet of flowers, fresh, sweet, intense. This beer is divine. Dark red/copper color. Almost no head but leaves a thick coating of lace in the glass neverless.  This beer is not a thirst quencher by any means. Perfect for after dinner, late night. Unbelievebly smooth but intensely complex.Hard to find any faults. This is my second pint tonight (10.5%) so it has a real kick. I will definitely heading back to Munster, IN soon. By the way check my thoughts on Alpha King and Dreadnaught Ales - AMESOME.

Beautiful red/gold, nice white foam, big and surprisingly balanced, 3 floyds is not a one-trick pony -- this is a very unique brew, very nice, very powerful. bright but not acidic. Big props to hopsrus.

Deep amber color. Small head. Aroma is floral hops and malts. A very big bold malty and hoppy barleywine. VERY smooth taste. The big rich malts are balanced by big floral citrusy hops. A very well balanced barleywine. The alcohol is not at all evident despite the 11.5%. VERY nice. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is surprisingly dry. Aftertaste is malty, with a lingering slight bitterness. Props to hopsrus.

Bottled from a growler: Clear copper color. Big centennial hop aroma. Nice amount of malt in the nose. Very well-balanced nose. Numbing alcohol flavor. Very sweet. Big malt backbone. Big promise in the aroma but didn't deliver in the flavor department. Still quite good although probably my least favorite of the big Three Floyds beers. Thanks to hopsrus for bottling and sending this out. Thanks to user_ex for sharing.

A beautiful ruby hue. Thin light tan head and lace. Aroma of caramel, peaches, hop resin and others.  Medium thick body, creamy and full with loads of flavor. Huge caramel malts, fruity slickness with loads of hops finishing it. I swear i taste watermelon jolly ranchers in the finish mixing with the hops. A damn good barleywine.

This reminds me of a maltier version of Avery Hog Heaven.  The hops are very much present, but it has a rounder, fuller, softer mouthfeel.  The ABV is very well hidden as well.  I could live without the grapfruit finish, which dropped the overall score down a little bit.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2006 Bomber. Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is medium orange-brown. Aroma is lightly malty (cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), lightly yeasty (dough), with notes of peach and alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lighlty to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 Really lovely deep ruby hue, very clear, with a small creamy fast-diminishing head.  Nose disappointingly two-dimensional, hoppy and alcoholic and thats it.  Flavor, there"s another story.  The trademark (well, seems like a trademark to me) 3Fs thick crushed-velvet mouthfeel hits you immediately, along with flavors of alcohol, oak, cherries and of course massive hops.  Along with SN Bigfoot, the best hoppy barleywine I"ve had yet, though I must say on the whole I prefer the older, mellower, sweeter versions of the style; this is not on the same level as Delafield"s Okauchee Scotchie or the "97 Lakefront, good as it is.

Next day, 2nd sample, slight rerate:  must have absorbed some bad odors from my car, or my sense of smell was whacked, because I get a lovely malty/dried fruit scent now; still not the very best BW I"ve had, but close.

Holy moly! Huge mouthfeel from all that body. Tiny head running up through a gold-red color. Very aromatic. A cool strawberry flavor comes up first and gives way to citrusy hops and chewy malt. Very warming. Enjoy carefully while youre judging the big body beauty pageant that is Behemoth!

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2005 Rerate: Bomber with pink wax. Filtered, hoppy (all Centennial it seems). Way citrusy. Totally devoid of character -- its not bad, but it is completely unorigianl now and uninspring. Perhaps this is because it was resampled after two Blaugies beers...Original: Not essentially all that different from the other big 4 by 3F Ive had since fedex delivered my package from hopsrus at 11:00 am this morning (6 hrs ago). I mean its good, the hop profile has all the usual suspects, but the barleywine character is subdued somehat as a result. Not my fave style anyway, though I am damn glad to have had the opportunity to try this monster. And I have certainly had a major hop infusion today.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: MAR 8, 2003 01'vintage draft:Pretty,hazy,ruby color.Aroma was intenesly,fruity and sweet.Flavors were well balanced for bordering on extreme.This was delicious. Glass drank out of growler.Mahogany with small but lasting ring of white head.Huge hoppy(grapefruit,citric),alcohol,thick malts.Palate is thick and coats.Huge caramelly sweetness in the front,followed by intense leafy hop flavors.Finish is sweet,spicy(alcohol)and not as bitter as expecting.Huge hop burps though.The only BW to rival Bigfoot in the hop depertment.IMO,this is more soft and appealing.Taste lingers forever.Really tasty.Horizontal still beats this out,as far as US bw's. Thanks to Racegoer,for carting around the growler for Jeff and I.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 As thick as oil, but smooth as silk.  Wonderfully hopped and very malty.  The only thing I can find wrong with this is that it may be a bit too sweet.  This is a great barley wine though.

2005 bottle, aged 4 years: Pours a cloudy dark amber ruby with a thin, wispy-lacing white head.  Aroma of sweet caramel and light fruity aged complexity.  Starts fairly full and caramely sweet with lots of aged cherry fruity complexity and some traces of citrusy flavoring hops.  Very different from the fresh version, but seems to have aged well.
Thanks to Racegoer for this one. A huge barleywine. Another huge beer from 3F. Hoppy with a malty caramel flavor to it. A great beer.
a wonderful balance of hops & malt. It has a loads of malt up front w/ a very dry finish. This is a world class winter warmer

Now this is a fantastic brew! Dark copper body with only a little head fighting its way through the thickness.Big malty body with a very nice hop presence. Aromas of cherry and alcohol greet you when you raise your glass. Another perfectly balanced brew. How do they do this. Either the floyds are master brewers with tremendous patience to go through all the hits and misses or they are the luckiest bastards in the world to have found the perfect balance in everything they brew. Either way anyone who has the pleasure of sampling one of their brews is the recipient of some masterful craftmanship.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Draft... This beer rocks!... The aroma is very malty, alcoholic and floral.
This sparkling clear amber beer has a small, creamy, khaki colored head. Mostly diminishing with excellent lacing. The flavor is rich and malty/sweet. Bursts of molasses and honey with lots of grapefruit and resin. Crazily full-bodied. with a syrupy mouthfeel. Lively carbonation. Long, sweet, clover-laden finish. These guys just cant go wrong.

A huge massive Homeric epic quality of a beer.  Like a Roman plum farm ready for harvest in the height of the Germanic empire.  Ralphm Wigum would say, I broke my Wookie.  Like an everlasting hoppy goobstooper exploding in my mouth like a thousand explosions in my mouth look forward to the exclamation of  a thousand Klingons yelling to Carl Sagan about Hawking on the event horizon.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2003 (4.6)On tap at Three Floyds and sleeping in a 1/2 growler in my beer fridge.HUGE beer, warming. Sweet, malty, hoppy,Question is how long will that growler last ? Go get you some !Re-rate Gravity Head 2003 -Vintage 2001 keg darker, and sweeter than the version at had at Nick Floyds,the smooth complexity of this beer really masks the strong ABV.Amazing !
UPDATED: MAR 7, 2003 Easily my favorite Barley.  Rivals Bigfoot in hops.  Sweet.  A balance between malt & hops.

A wonderful, beautiful barleywine.  Notes of alcohol, vanilla, caramel, fruits (peach, plums, other soft fruits).  A really sweet barley wine with a nice hop finish.  Brilliant.  Another beer well-done by Three Floyds.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2005 22 oz, waxed dipped bottle (first bottle release, fresh): resiny grapefruit aroma, sharp alcohol and thick pine.  Bubble gummy hop flavours with sticky chlorophyll and caramel hop juice.  Pine needles shape the finish and tasty hop-belches ensure quickly.  Not quite as good as I remember from the growlers I sampled, but perhaps 6-8 months in the bottle will solve that7/4/8/4/16

Growler, November 2002:  Deep cedar red.  Hoppy alcohol nose.  A deep warming eases the body and the mind, blissful thoughts fill my head as the caramel and fruit swirl in my mouth.  3 Floyds: please dont ever stop. 8/5/8/4/17
Strong content, flavors, what more can you say about these guys? Another great Three Floyds beer...
Wonderfully balanced American barley wine ,no vineous-soy or oxidized flavors but Smooth Carmel and pineapple,mixed with and awesome hoppy aroma and well masked alcohol makes this a true classic!

One of my all time favorites..!The best beer for a cold winters night. Big grapefruit hoppy aroma.  This stuff is LARGE by all accounts. Beautiful, strong AND smooth! Do yourself a favor and get a hold of a Behemoth Blonde Barley Wine.

3Fs can do no wrong, and this exemplifies the good things they do with beer: sweet toffee and grapefruit in the nose, and a well-struck balance between a big, sweet malt body and bitter/citrusy hops. Lingers nicely on the palate. Could have a fuller mouthfeel (though that might be rectified when not cask conditioned).

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 2001; draft: Gooey, sappy, chewy malt  aroma with the hallmark Three Floyd's fruity hop combo. Vicious, sappy palate. Flavors match the aroma to a T with just enough underlying sappy, slightly bready malts. Zero trace of the abv. Absolutely juicy, explosive strawberry  esters expound on the palate. Stellar hop belches accompany the sticky malts at the finish. Gorgeous stuff.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: My champ of the Real Ale Fest. Dont let anyone tell you that Pizza Port beath this, NO WAY! Malty with a dry finish. Alchohol is well covered. I need to compare this with Bells Third Coast Old Ale head to head.

Wow! Three Floyds does it again. Had this on tap in Chicago and it was fabulous. Full of sweet carmel malt flavor, incredibly smooth. Hops balanced well by the malt. Not quite as good as Third Coast Old Ale but very close in my book.
This is a big, hoppy BW. Definately smooth going down with the typical BW heat. Great offering from 3Fs!! Keep em coming.
WHOA MOMMA!, This beer is strong, hoppy, big nose, big taste anhd a killer ABV. I have sampled all the the 3Fs beers and they are excellent.

Well-balanced, but definitely leans towards the hop.  In fact, this may be the hoppiest barley wine I’ve ever
had - certainly the driest.
